review: If you like first person dungeon crawlers you'll probably enjoy this. There were a few parts that annoyed me near the end and the sound is bugged so you'll need to lower it down on your system but other then that it was a fun challenging experience. Also this is the version with the White Palace which means it has slightly different endings and gameplay, the Black Palace version is sold on Steam in a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072740436', 'num_games_owned': 81, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1707850026}
review: my character is finally level 2

author: {'steamid': '76561197993620814', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4232, 'last_played': 1507352642}
review:
This is a great game if you know what you're getting into. It's an old-school dungeon crawler in the vein of the first few Wizardry games, which were somewhat popular in the west but way more so in Japan, so games like this have never really fallen out of favor over there. Expect a high level of difficulty, character creation that leaves you feeling like you're missing something, some necessary grinding, an uneven difficulty curve, and other aspects of decidedly old-school design. That being said, it's also quite rewarding when you are able to do well at it. 

Also has a cool soundtrack.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001894598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1689190364}
review: The game is fun but these types of games are niche and you either like them a lot or you don't, as others have said it's challenging in parts while being very easy in other parts and it just kinda randomly spikes with certain encounters but it's not too bad. It's slow to get going and you'll probably want to restart when you learn how to play. Also the game doesn't auto save, you need to manually save the game in town, Don't forget to save before closing the game.. I only recommend this game If you like these specific types of games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010851321', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 4438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3292, 'last_played': 1680640035}
review:
Not my favorite Experience DRPG gameplay-wise, but it's solid and has a really unique artstyle and level design. The 3D graphics are pretty bad, but the environments get the point across and are really just a backdrop for the absolutely gorgeous spritework. I will go on the record as saying the lives system is stupid and I hate it, but it's part of the game so I've learned to live with it (save scumming ftw), but it's not a dealbreaker for me.

If you're new to this genre and looking for some other recommends:
Undernauts: Labyrinth of Yomi
Operation Abyss & Babel: New Tokyo Legacy
Mary Skelter 1, 2 & Finale
Wizardry: Labyrinth of Lost Souls 
Labyrinth of Refrain: Coven of Dusk
Class of Heroes 1 & 2 (PSP)
Shin Megami Tensei: Strange Journey (DS) or Redux (3DS)

author: {'steamid': '76561198071964155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 1427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1674943892}
review: A really Hard Dungeon Crawling game but it has some fun to figure class build and some strat to play. Imagine Darkest Dungeon But has mobs spike issue and grinding to the point that first level can drop a mob that is 10-20 more level then you to one shot your entire team. Now also include more choices for you to mess up and lose because you need more HP then speed but get still lose since the mob you encounter is several level above  to one shot you as you grind. At point I think cheating is fair way to enjoy the game with its BS gimmicks. (you can cheat the money but finding way to give you more skill point or level is hard).

author: {'steamid': '76561198043734189', 'num_games_owned': 466, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1668506289}
review:
this game is not for the average player
mainly because even in its easier dificulty has a lot of unfair situations, like, siddenly finding a enemy what can one shot your team just because it managed to hit
it also requires serius grindind if you want to pogress thro it, both in levels and gear, and because characters can permanently die, if you lose a character... welp, back to the grind!, so you have to not only grind for your main team, but also for your subtitute team as well!

author: {'steamid': '76561197962872327', 'num_games_owned': 2329, 'num_reviews': 191, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1668930011}
review: You're a dude who somehow survived a plane crash. An old man is like, damn, you da chosen one. And then he pulls some bullshit, and tries to kill you. It's a strange game. I like it though, kind of weird first person shooter without guns.

author: {'steamid': '76561198238170268', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 2868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2846, 'last_played': 1662778018}
review: I've played this on Vita and it kinda sucks this port has less content than that version. But aside from that it's a solid dungeon crawler, it has a challenging curve and despite the occasional cringey fanservice, it has some ok story too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068517619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 7996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 590, 'last_played': 1671286581}
review:
I think the game is quite challenging. There is a a genuine sense of excitement when you ambush to see what might be in the chest. There is always the danger of death and the game is definitely not easy. Interesting use of skills and tactics make for a good dungeon crawler.

I played it with a controller. Xbox 360 controller.

After spending more time on this game I am quite taken by certain aspects of it and am now ready to expand my review. 

The game has many many interesting dungeons that employ various tactics and require you to take a varied group and use different skills and spells to get over the bosses that you encounter. I was very surprised by how much depth the combat had because between the skills that require you to use certain prior skills to activate or the use spells that can have different durations and potency depending on what you need, there are also items you can use and you can also swap weapons. There is also the added bonus of using your morale for special attacks , buffs or debuffs or to simple run away.

I loved the hand drawn art as you can see by the number of hours I have already put in I am enjoying it very much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198215525996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 9721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2544, 'last_played': 1690066664}
review:
Sad, it's another dungeon crawler that has received mixed reviews. It was actually a very good game, and the game port had no problems so far as I played it.

This game is another very good modern take on a wizardry-like game by Japanese developer Experience.inc.
The multiclassing and skills are a bit confusing, so I really suggest reading some guides about multiclassing and reading the forum first before you start the game, so you don't make the same mistake as I did and have to do another new game with a better start.

The game starts off fairly casually, but from mid-game to endgame, it truly defines GRIND.
The only way to get strong in this game is through equipment. All equipment in this game must be grinded in the dungeon (with using ambush spots until your morale runs out, then coming back to the hub and trying it again and again until you get strong equipment.)
The teleport item is really scarce in this game, unlike Operation Abyss (and Operation Abyss's endgame magic had a teleport, so it's better).
So you pretty much must walk back manually in this game, it's quite tiring

This game's not for everyone, but it's quite bearable for me at least (and I took a lot of breaks playing this game because of how punishing it is).
Â 
tbh, I liked the experience inc. older Operation Abyss title more than this game, it's the game that makes me fall in love with this genre, and it's more player friendly with a reasonable price for revivals than this game that needs a ridiculously crazy amount of money to revive (around 1/3 of your money for your whole playthrough is gone) or choose in-game hours to revive or recover character life points.It's quite another grind since the only way to pass time is by fighting enemies again (I forgot how many to be exact, but it's more than 40+ fights).
Â 
And the enemies.. bosses, ah yes, those can instantly kill you easily, bosses needed to be debuffed, and you needed to buff your party properly or you'll receive instakill (I'm not joking, late-game bosses are a nightmare; you need to buff each of your characters av (avoid) to 99, set up a wall, etc. or you'll die). Endgame's regular enemies can also kill you if you are not careful. It's very brutal, and reloading the save is easier since it saves you time grinding to pass time to revive your character.

I can't count how many times I've reloaded in this game, probably hundreds, and a lot of loot was lost. It's very brutal.
I really wish the items were like in Operation Abyss. In Operation Abyss, there's even an item that can save your progress before the boss, but in SOSC it doesn't exist, so if you're about to fight the boss (or accidentally do so), just pray you'll win, or good luck walking through those dungeons again.
I suggest the safest route though, go through the dungeon, return to the hub, save your progress, and come back for the bosses (I know it's a pain, I did this too, so...)

Still, it's still a good game, just with some weird game design. I still prefer their older title, it's simpler.

edit: It has controller support, and it works very well with my PS4 controller, unlike what other negative reviews said.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121488646', 'num_games_owned': 652, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 4055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4055, 'last_played': 1647486178}
review:
Full In-Depth Review video in Indonesian
https://youtu.be/P9TEpR3EDb0

I wish there's a middle score in steam review, but I think the flaws of this game kinda overshadow the goods.

At the first 20-30 hours I really enjoyed it, then it became a painful grindfest. The lack of new mechanic from midgame makes it easier to get bored in the game.

It is still a good Dungeon Crawler, I'd still recommend this to newer player since there's also a Beginner Difficulty and also a quite complex story for its genre, even though it has messy writing and translation. The game isn't hard enough to be called unforgiving, the main campaign is still fair. The post-game dungeons are different story though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054216330', 'num_games_owned': 437, 'num_reviews': 244, 'playtime_forever': 4597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4597, 'last_played': 1646153485}
review:
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b][u]Eine MaÃŸgeschneiderte Gruppe- 
Charaktererstellung mit TÃ¼cken und das Klassensystem[/u][/b]
Bevor man Strangers of Sword City Ã¼berhaupt etwas tut, gelangt man auch schon in das CharaktererstellungsmenÃ¼, wo man seinen Hauptcharakter erstellt und neben einigen anderen Einstellungen auch seine Klasse festlegen.
Auf die selbe Weise kann man sich ein wenig spÃ¤ter auch GefÃ¤hrten basteln, bei denen man sogar die Rasse festlegen kann, die lediglich die anfÃ¤nglichen Statuswerte beeinflusst. Das Aussehen (Portrait) der Charaktere kann frei gewÃ¤hlt werden. Man kann also beispielsweise einem Zwergenkrieger das Portrait eines Elfenmagiers geben.

ZusÃ¤tzlich kann man bei den Charakteren das [b]Alter[/b] bestimmen, was eben so wie die Rasse keinen Einfluss auf das Aussehen, wohl aber auf das Gameplay hat. Ein alter Charakter bekommt bei seiner Erstellung mehr Attributspunkte zugeteilt, die er frei verteilen kann, hat aber weniger Lebenspunkte.

Ein recht interessantes Feature ist das [b]Klassensystem[/b], das es einem Charakter erlaubt, jederzeit aber nur eine Begrenzte Anzahl an Malen seine Klasse zu wechseln. 
Jeder Skill, den ein Charakter in einer vorherigen Klasse erlernt hat, kann in einen freien Skillslot eingesetzt und verwendet werden, wodurch andere AusrÃ¼stung verwendbar werden kann oder bestimmte FÃ¤higkeiten genutzt werden kÃ¶nnen. Auf diese Weise kann man beispielsweise einen Magier, der zuvor ein Ritter war, eine PlattenrÃ¼stung anlegen oder einem Ritter der zuvor Kleriker war, Heilzauber beibringen.
Ein Nachteil hierbei ist, dass der Charakter seine neue Klasse mit der hÃ¤lfte des Levels der vorherigen Klasse startet. War man zuvor Level zwanzig, landet man also wieder auf Level zehn.

[b][u]Die Sache mit dem Sterben[/u][/b]
Jeder Charakter hat zwischen einem und drei [b]Lebenspunkten[/b] und jedes Mal, wenn er (oder sie) Ã¼ber die Wupper geschickt wird, verringert sich deren Anzahl. Hat ein Charakter keine Lebenspunkte mehr, stirbt er wirklich und ist weg. Man kann zwar die Lebenspunkte und die KampffÃ¤higkeit des Charakters zwar mittels Items wieder her stellten, diese sind allerdings recht selten und eines senkt sogar die maximale Anzahl der Lebenspunkte dafÃ¼r dass es einen wiederherstellt.
Die Standardmethode, Charaktere zu regenerieren ist also, sie in einer speziellen Einrichtung zu lassen, wo man sie entweder (gegen eine horende Summe) instant wiederherstellen kann oder sie einige Ingametage ruhen lassen kann, was fÃ¼r den Spieler mehrere Spielstunden des Abfarmens von Gegnern in den Dungeons bedeutet.

[b][u]Dungeons, ÃœberfÃ¤lle und Bossjagten[/u][/b]
FÃ¼r das [b]Vorranschreiten der Handlung[/b] im Spiel ist es erforderlich, die sogenannten "Lineage Typen", quasi Bossgegner, aufzuspÃ¼hren und zur Strecke zu bringen. Als Preis fÃ¼r den Sieg Ã¼ber Ã¼ber einen solchen Gegner erhÃ¤lt man einen Blutkristall, den man einer von drei Personen geben kann, die dann je nach Person einen Segen springen lÃ¤sst. Wem man die Kristalle gibt, beeinflusst auÃŸerdem das Ende des Spiels.
 
Ein Teil der Herrausforderung ist es, das potentielle Opfer ersteinmal zu finden. Manche Lineages, erscheinen als Randomencounter, andere greifen in KÃ¤mpfe ein, die lange andauern oder erscheinen erst nach einer Anzahl X an getÃ¶teten Feinden.
Die Dungeons selbst warten teils mit einigen interessanten Gimmiks auf wie BeschrÃ¤nkungen und ZustÃ¤nde die die Gruppe erleidet. In einem Dungeon sind Magier und Kleriker nutzlos weil nicht gezaubert werden kann, in einem anderen kÃ¶nnen Kampftechniken nicht angewandt werden. Aber auch klassiker wie GeheimtÃ¼ren, rutschige BÃ¶den und Fallen finden sich hier. 

Um in Dungeons an [b]AusrÃ¼stung[/b] zu kommen, plÃ¼ndert man nicht etwa herumstehende Schatztruhen, sondern lauert an bestimmten Orten Feindgruppen auf, die eben diese mit sich herumtragen. 
Die voraussichtliche QualitÃ¤t und Art der Items in der Truhe erkennt man an eben der Truhe, allerdings kann auch in einer prunkvollen Truhe MÃ¼ll enthalten sein, wodurch das alles viel mit GlÃ¼ck zu tun hat.

[b][u]Meckern auf hohem Niveau[/u][/b]
Eine der wohl hervorstechendsten SchwÃ¤chen des Spiels ist nicht ein mal der Grindfaktor, sondern das Balancing, das teils schon ins absurde verhunzt ist. Einige Gegner (auch Bosse) sind in der Lage, einem Charakter direkt einen kritischen Treffer zuzufÃ¼gen, wodurch dieser instant kampfunfÃ¤hig wird und natÃ¼rlich einen Lebenspunkt verliert. Man kann dem entgegen wirken, wenn man einen bestimmten Skill ausrÃ¼stet, den allerdings nur eine Klasse hat. Man muss also besagten Charakter ersteinmal in dieser Klasse aufleveln bis er den Skill erlernt und das Aufleveln eines Charakters dauert eine Weile.
Was das Spiel fÃ¼r mich dann komplett gekillt hat, waren zwei Dinge:
Zum einen [b]die Items[/b]. Die meisten HeiltrÃ¤nke und offensive Items wie Brandbomben wirken bei Benutzung einen Zauber. Dieser wird durch die Magiekraft des Benutzers gespeist. 
HeiÃŸt im Klartext: Ein reiner Krieger, der eine Potion verwendet erzeilt mit dieser kaum einen Effekt, wÃ¤hrend ein Kleriker damit annÃ¤hrend an seinen Heilzauber herankommt. Warum in dreiteufelsnamen sollte man eine Potion verwenden, wenn man mit dem selben Charakter einen Heilzauber nutzen kann?! 
Fans des Spiels wÃ¼rden jetzt wohl den Dungeon erwÃ¤hnen, in dem man nicht zaubern kann. 
Ja, hier wÃ¤hren die Dinger tatsÃ¤chlich von Nutzen und man kÃ¶nnte auch seinen Kleriker und Magier mitschleppen. Allerdings ist das so ziemlich der einzige Dungeon dieser Art und so nÃ¶tig hat man die Items hier auch nicht. Es gibt auch Heilitems, die einen fixen betrag an Hitpoints heilen, aber spÃ¤testens im NG+ sind die eh nutzlos.
Der andere Faktor ist wohl ein Bug, nÃ¤mlich [b]nicht verwendbare Zauber[/b]. Beim Aufleveln des Magiers und des Klerikers, plopt gelegentlich die Nachricht auf, dass dieser einen neuen Zauber gelernt hat. 
Leider erscheinen einige Zauber einfach nicht in seiner Zauberliste und auch ein Klassenwechsel und das AusrÃ¼sten des entsprechenden Skills, schafft hier keine Abhilfe.

[h1]Schwierigkeitsgrad[/h1]
Der Schwierigkeitsgrad des Spiels kann zu Beginn eingestellt und spÃ¤ter mittels eines Items verÃ¤ndert werden. Allerdings ist das Spiel selbst auf dem leichtesten Schwierigkeitsgrad recht grindlastig und teils vom Zufall abhÃ¤ngig.

[h1]Soundtrack, Grafik, Steuerung[/h1]
Der Soundtrack ist wohl die groÃŸe StÃ¤rke des Spiels. Die gespielten StÃ¼cke sind hochwertig und absolut hÃ¶renswert. Sie unterstreichen die Stimmung im Spiel und schaffen die richtige Atmosphere.

Die Grafik ist recht ordentlich. Die MÃ¶glichkeit, eigene Charakterportraits zu importieren ist ebenfalls vorhanden und man kann zwischen zwei Grafikstilen fÃ¼r die NPCs und Zwischensequenzen wÃ¤hlen.
Die Umgebung wird allerdings nicht beeinflusst, wodurch die NPCs in einem anderen als dem Standardstil fehl am Platz wirken.

Das Spiel kann recht komfortabel mit Maus und Tastatur gespielt werden. 

[h1]Zusammenfassung[/h1]
[b]Pro:[/b]
[list]
[*] Mehrklassen System 
[*] Mehrere Enden
[*] Viele Items und AusrÃ¼stungsgegenstÃ¤nde
 [/list]

[b]Kontra:[/b]
[list]
[*] Seltsames Balancing
[*] Grindlastig
[*] Speichern und Neuladen nur an einem Ort im Spiel mÃ¶glich

[/list]
[b]Neutral:[/b]
[list]
[*] Permadeathsystem
[/list]

[b]bekannte Bugs[/b]
Magier und Kleriker haben keinen Zugriff auf manche zuvor gelernte Zauber

[b]Fazit:[/b]
Stranger of Sword City verschenkt viel Potential durch die Komposition aus Grindlastigkeit und Features, die grinding erfordern sowie dem Balancing, das teils zum einen willkÃ¼rlich wirkt und zum anderen kaum Sinn ergibt.

 [b]------------------------------------------------------------------------

[i]Wenn ihr weitere ansprechende Reviews lesen wollt, 
dann folgt doch der [url= https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32139821/}]GermanReviewGroup[/url].[/i]

------------------------------------------------------------------------[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198060470937', 'num_games_owned': 771, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1928, 'last_played': 1522636586}
review:
-It's Narnia, the Anime Dungeon Crawler.  You get sucked into the world where the missing socks hide.
-Randomly unbeatable enemies are randomly unbeatable.
-Characters can get injured, benching them while you take out the non-hot girls to run around the early areas again, for the eleventeenth time because you rightly ignored their development.
-You can get hours into the game and the totality of the story you experience is, creepy old man, hot chick recruits you to be a hero in garbageland because they are weak and you is strong, and... something about getting something from special types of critters.
-The character and battle graphics are beautiful and are kinda animatedish, but the overworld is worse than some (insert naughty game genre) games.
-Not that I'd buy those type of games... I've just heard from a friend (yeah, an acquaintance at best) that the overworld design tends to be simple and ugly.
-Don't believe me?  I've got over 500 games in my library, good luck finding them (since they totally don't exist).
-the battle system is aight, nothing new.
-I still have it installed and want to play it, for some reason (possibly subliminal messages being beamed into my brain by the Narnian oligarchy).
-Because I can't resist (their secret magic laser hypnotizator pierces aluminum foil (I can't find tin foil anywhere)), I will give this game a "buy it on sale."
-Special hats not included.


Don't look through my games.  You're wasting your time because there aren't any there, plus sometimes my friends (who aren't imaginary!!) hypothetically gift me things as a gag.
Acquaintances, really.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019850620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2217, 'last_played': 1635605051}
review:
Positives:
     * Reminiscent of the original Wizardry on NES.  Playing this really brought out the nostalgia.
     * Character VAs are pretty good.  Characters themselves are interesting and unique.
     * Lots of classes to choose from right from the beginning.  There is no unlocking classes.
     * Skill slots under mastery allow for a wide variety of builds.
     * Action redo.  A huge time saver for trash mobs.
     * Two equipped weapon sets per character.
     * Each area had its own unique theme and unique enemies.  Very few enemies showed up in multiple locations.

Meh:
     * Reappearing Lineage Types.  Killed them once and it was tedious to have to kill them again, especially since I couldn't get gems again.
     * Factions and Divinities.  Felt like there could have been a better way of handling this.  Plus other than the ending helping a specific faction more didn't really change anything.
     * Weapon types could use a little better balancing.  Once you start getting skill slots most weapon types were pointless.
     * Mumic and unique weapons.  Very rarely did I use them.

Negatives:
     * No way to move characters between front and back ranks during battle (that I found).
     * Steep difficulty change to move between 50 and 55 morale.  I was being forced to fight one of two 5* Lineages to get my fourth gem so that I could get 55 morale to open up the Sea area.  Previous to those fights I had only fought 3 stars and 1 5 star that never really attacked me.

Loved the game and definitely recommend it if you enjoy dungeon crawlers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067047244', 'num_games_owned': 1245, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 8126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8126, 'last_played': 1559588258}
review: Honestly a game i hate to love. In my head i call it Stranger of Grind city, because thats what it is. Endless grinding for better gear so you can tackle new dungeon, rinse and repeat. The monster designs are cool, the art is very nice but there is nothing for me to elevate this game above the slog and tedium of the gameplay. Dont even get me started on the fucking water dungeon that has a extremely tiring built in tile system puzzle thing. Basically you have to choose the right boost tiles, but you can only know this by looking it up online and you have to go that same route every time you come down there. Or the godawful spooky level with the trapdoors and poison traps. Ugh. I feel like the game just suffers from bad level design and a really really steep grind curve. Like you are just obligated to grind because thats how the gear system works. So the ambush thing seems neat, but is in reality just a big headache. The game tries to be oldschool, but the only oldschool thing is the time you will be spending on that grind ff style. I even turned the difficulty down a notch in the second to last dungeon just to make my time with it shorter. Maybe if you like those oldschool jrpgs thisll float your boat, but i think you are better off with say SMT nocturne or some shit like that. Cant reccomend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029301754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7452, 'last_played': 1510470557}
review:
One of the best dungeon crawlers I've ever played. The gameplay might be too grindy for some, but the challenge of tackling the fearsome dungeons at low level is heart pounding.

The atmostphere and music are literally the best I've ever experienced. Love it when you're fighting a normal group of enemies, then the screen flashes and the music changes as a powerful lineage enters the battle and begins to wipe your group.

author: {'steamid': '76561198316768692', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1628644905}
review: Fun dungeon crawler. Not a super in depth story. Best played in windows mode while listening to music or a podcast

review: This product is a bad offer. If you want to play the game (which itself is fun) buy the one bundled with â€œSaviors of Sapphire Wingsâ€. Iâ€™m very salty that I donâ€™t get a discount for the 2 games bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966338579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 9033, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9029, 'last_played': 1640383011}
review:
I'd probably buy the remaster that is bundled with Saviors of Sapphire Wings instead of this version, now that it is available.

The game is fun, challenging, and rewarding.  I wasn't the biggest fan of the story but it had me interested at times and the production values of the game are solid.  The music is good, the sound is ok, the graphics are nice and detailed artwork.

TL;DR If you enjoy wizardry like games then this one is a good choice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112947153', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4698, 'last_played': 1481150105}
review: This was a fun game to play, very much like 'Strange Journey', but a little harder. My advise for anyone reading this is to buckle yourself in for farming/grinding from time to time. Enemies tend to rocket in difficulty in each new area.

author: {'steamid': '76561198323536377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1625925456}
review: Not sure why people give this game bad reviews. Sure it's not perfect dungeon crawler and can be challenging sometimes, but game is pretty decent. Controls a little bit confusing, but you can quickly get used to it. Art,  character customization, music  and decent story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060296005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 37746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22582, 'last_played': 1629301347}
review: Insane difficulty and incredible character customization. Perfect game if you're into Wizardry dungeon crawlers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064754199', 'num_games_owned': 406, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 9716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9716, 'last_played': 1611218178}
review:
I like this game, but being honest it's hard to give a recommendation because it's not my favourite of Experience Inc's games (that would be Demon Gaze 2, which is never coming to Steam) and it's not even close to being NISA's best translation effort. There's a number of skill/item descriptions that are vague or wrong, and even the main story is written a bit awkwardly. There are a couple of dungeons that are outright unfun. Whether or not equipment has +stats is totally random, with no way of manual upgrade. Music either doesn't exist or is unremarkable.

I do like the class system, even if I don't get why they restricted the number of times you can switch. The maps aren't too huge or too small. Story's serviceable.

If this were the "Revisited" edition of the game, which improves many mechanics, I'd give a thumbs up, but the Steam version's a 6/10 as-is. Enjoyed it enough to finish it, more than I can say about Operation Abyss.

EDIT: NISA actually did recently release the Revisted version on Steam, but it's bundled with another game. As said, I do recommend that version more so it may be worth checking out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134857852', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 9044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9044, 'last_played': 1562670649}
review:
I don't really get all the hate on this game.
Even if it is indeed REAAAALLLLY hard sometimes, that is part of the fun !
Imo its a really cool and pretty good rpg, with good graphics (if you don't choose the "out of place anime option") and an enjoyable story.
You will need a bit of time to grind your character but it is not a problem, and the perma death stuffs are great.
I only lost one character so it was not too frustrating for me (but hey, i spend half of my time playing stupidly hard RPG so i tend to know what i do) and it had some stress to every boss fights, its not just a "Go to the boss, save, try, notice you need to level up a bit, loose, farm, try again", if you just rush to the next one, you might have to either wait to get your characters back, or make a totally new team, depend of how greedy you are with them.

So ok its clearly not noob friendly, but as soon as you start to understands the basics, it is a ton of fun.
Already finished it twice (And i played the hard difficulty from the get go), and i might do it again one day, just want to forget it a bit to enjoy it almost as much as my first run.

Oh and the ost is amazing !!

Sorry for the few English mistakes, not my native language

author: {'steamid': '76561198968361120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1672923005}
review: This is a decent dungeon crawler that's spoilt by the overly harsh death penalty. Your weak back row characters can get one hit killed without warning leaving you waiting 7 in game days or 84 battles just to recover them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111520979', 'num_games_owned': 307, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1614624836}
review:
I don't know man, this game is balanced like absolute shit
I love the art, the music is nice enough, the story is kinda ok, but the gameplay just suffers from huge stupid decisions
This is a pure dungeon crawler, build a party and just get into the dungeon to kill stuff
Problem is, killing stuff gets repetitive real fast, and the game gets so fucking hard you have to grind for hours for levels and gear and then pray to christ that the boss doesn't use THAT ONE MOVE
Im sorry, but you really have to be insane to enjoy this

author: {'steamid': '76561198077757370', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1613672920}
review: There's better dungeon crawlers if you want a good dungeon crawler from the same publisher they have one called Labyrinth of Refrain I thought that game was clunky, but this game made that game look like a sports car. A lot of cool stuff dragged down by anti player game design and chunky game play. I have 1.3 hours and I feel like it was 4 hours. I see where they learned from their mistakes and I think they are improving per game this is the worst of the bunch and it shows just play this one and then play refrain. I am not recommending this game, but I am recommending this company.

review:
the only good grid-based dungeon-crawler i've ever played apart from "Ancients I: Death Watch" on MS-DOS.

âœ… includes anime waifus

author: {'steamid': '76561198118749760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 8314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8314, 'last_played': 1611383554}
review:
This game is too hard, so picking beginner difficulty is highly recommended. 

One tip: Hold down "A" on Xbox Controller to identify items fast and sell fast.

Still too hard? Wait for the updated version Stranger of Sword City Revisited. Planned Release March 16, 2021. With a lot of improvements that make the game sound too easy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009067077', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1609978570}
review:
Update
----------------

Runs under Linux Mint 19 (Ubuntu) using the (relatively new) Proton 5.13.  Sometimes still crashes at launch, but 2-4 tries and it will be stable each time.

+++ Ooo-oo! Custom portraits! I love these.  Gotta scan in and color some drawings.

Well....custom characters are not intuitive:  
1) Go to Steam\steamapps\common\Stranger of Sword City\PICTUREGATE\   
2) Choose a folder per character   
3) Each folder need 4 files labeled as userImgA,B,C,and D.  thats an i not L.   
4) userImgA [746 x 720 pixels. This is your main character image!]    
    userImgB [350 x 380 pixels. This is the portrait that displays in your party.]    
    userImgC [160 x 240 pixels. This is your character creation/selection portrait.]     
    userImgD [146 x 32 pixels. This is the mini icon that displays during combat.]     
5) Look in the USERDATA folder for examples of framing.     
6) Save as either.jpg, .bmp, or .png  Png and Bmp are recommended for the transparency layer.     
7) yes, userImgA is wider than it is tall.     
8) IMPORTANT, images must be imported in the options menu.  The game doesnt tell you this unless you f*** around for 3 hours with the Userdata folder enough that an error appears.       
9) Where in the Options??? There are tiny TAB buttons in the  corners of the screen.  Miss them?  I sure did.  hence the 3 hours of trying to figure this out.  

Cool! Now I have my character for this fantasy game!  I have imported my DnD elf cleric!

---The main character must be human.   S***.  Continue anyways and deal with dialogue as it comes.  

---Ooooooh.  The schoolgirl on the cover isn't japanese fanservice.....there are too many not so subtle hints that you, the PC, are a human who fell through a portal from earth and all earthlings are stronger here, hence the schoolgirl using a bastard sword.  Well......there goes my fantasy game immersion.  

---Combat! I read that it's no cakewalk, even for beginner, but seriously, all the mobs are 10 levels higher and one shot me.  Ok, I'll just defend and heal while the schoolgirl swings for 10 turns.  I still die.  what fun.  Hope it doesnt count against my hearts for permadeath or this will be REAL short.  She revives me, no consequence, she tells me to be more confident and attack more.

Next fight. dead turn 1.  Schoolgirl diablo-click till win.  fun.
Next fight. Dead turn 1. Schoolgirl diablo-clicks twice as long for a win.
(Yes, I used her Taunt skill.  They all still attacked me.)

Save point.  Motivation is fully gone now.

It may sound petty, but the first impressions are: 
1) No, you are either a boy or girl human.  Athlete or a gamer.
2) Look how much you suck at everything!  Be careful of one hit permadeath! (Good for DarkSouls, bad for RNG evasion)
3) We broke our own rule of permadeath to show you how much cooler our characters are compared to yours.  

I am building a sandcastle, it must look traditional, A bully can randomly kick it over, I can do nothing; the bully's sister will beat up the bully.  Nothing matters because she is still grouped with he bully and my sandcastle is still smashed.

==========
Original
-----------------

Ive never gotten it to launch on

Intel 2.4G xeon server 8core
windows 7
32Gb Ram
Nvidia 970

Ryzen 5 3700
16GB Ram
nvidia 1660ti
Windows 10

Microsoft Surface 3 Pro
Windows 10

even tried the "install on C: fix"

author: {'steamid': '76561198432170536', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1634549455}
review: This is my first dungeon crawler. I love how the gameplay is going so far. It's pretty simple at a glance but there's a level of customization that you can't really experience in more traditional kinds of RPGs. I also like the fact that you can insert custom portraits you can use when making characters. It's like playing a TRPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054462873', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2206, 'last_played': 1611254638}
review: Scratches the itch left by the Wizardry game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034888313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 5390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5390, 'last_played': 1608330567}
review:
Stranger of Sword City is one of those games where you need to follow a guide from level 1. It's an old-school dungeon crawler with the usual "reincarnation" mechanic - meaning that if you don't meticulously plan every level from the start, by following a specific guide to the classes and skills, you will find yourself at a loss at the end of the game.

Add to that the fact that end-game enemies have multiple unavoidable instant-kill attacks (with no way to rez) and you have a very frustrating experience for the player. After nearly 49 hours in this playthrough I realized I'd messed up my reincarnation strategy (should have gone up to level 99 each time) and my group even at 99 wasn't powerful enough to handle the instant-kill attacks of the last bosses. Bosses also do an unavoidable "grab" mechanic, a full heal, and other nasty tricks - meaning even with infinite health you're always on the back foot. Divinities, which are supposed to protect you from effects, do not work when you are "grabbed", so you die even playing appropriately.

Story isn't bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022298610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 153, 'playtime_forever': 2066, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2066, 'last_played': 1606943158}
review:
I got this for 4â‚¬ on a sale. For that price the game was ok . Grinding was boring and they should have made it more "streamlined" story is what it is, all characters do look great, but then again, they are just still images. Game can be quite hard at some points, and only real solution fr it is to grind for gear. Permadeath was a b**ch. (your main cant die but your party can). Soundtrack was good.
If you are into dungeon crawlers, i'm shure there are better games out there; but if you do come across this on a sale give it a go ( and if you don't feel like pointless grinding, there are "ways around it)

author: {'steamid': '76561198375027402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 7457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2889, 'last_played': 1682301003}
review: Pretty cool game. Very Grindy and a bit difficult, but a solid dungeon crawler. I like to go into games blind and figure them out but I suggest looking at some guides and stuff for info as some things arent very clear.  The game is tough enough without needing to stumble through things.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046079255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3351, 'last_played': 1607634093}
review:
This game... I like this game and whenever I get an urge to play a dungeon crawler, this game is the one I want to play and thats for one reason: Difficulty

The difficulty is... interesting, and not for everyone. It's possible to lose... easily, but I've never felt it was unfair. The enemies keep you on your toes, even on the first dungeon. Most enemies that you encounter will be in a small bracket (first dungeon expect 10-13), but every so often you can meet enemies (as the same type as normal) 10 or so levels higher... and these come with higher stats as you would expect. I like this, because whilst your going through the normal stuff, it's easy to just spam the fast attack and watch things die, but if you try that with these guys, you'll suffer, and all you need to avoid it, is check the enemy levels by choosing the fight command first. 
Running away is easy and not only do you get your first divinity to run, but you have a command, can buy smoke bombs or use the basic wand to help. Also since the encounters are random, should you need to pass an encounter you can always challenge it again to get new enemies (hopefully easier ones).
Another part of the difficulty I like is the wandering monsters. The initial dungeon has an access to a mid dungeon, and whilst hunting for equipment or sometimes just wandering around, you can stumble on enemies from that dungeon... which can hurt you far more than you expect (one of the enemies can party wipe easily) compared to what their levels suggest (although they are usually higher than the standard enemies). These enemies are often very different to what you should be expecting, and once you've played it a bit, you get to recognise which ones you can deal with and which ones to avoid. This is just another reason I like this game, it places encounters that are usually better to run from than to tackle and does it in a more natural way.

This is not a game where you turn off playing it, it has too many ways to trip up a careless player and yet I never blame the game for being unfair, since all these ways are easy to identify. I often end up with player deaths from thinking I'm safe, and not keeping an eye on party health or the enemies I encounter.

The bosses are interesting and have a nice difficulty scale in the wanted screen, allowing you to plan how to deal with them, or better yet, how to avoid them until you can deal with them. Some of the bosses are true nightmares, where you end up running from battles if you stay too long. However, this just adds to the sense of satisfaction you get from progressing through a dungeon. You learn to beat the enemies quickly to get the rewards without worrying about the boss.

Aside from the enemy difficulty, I also like the themes the dungeons have, whether it prevents spell use, skill use or just is full of spirit enemies that need certain weapon properties or a wizard. All the dungeons have something defining them and I've never felt bored or that it was repetitive when going through them. These themes also add to the challenge and it allows the player to consider the equipment they are using when challenging the dungeons. Your not always aiming for the strongest weapons, sometimes weapons with elemental properties, or spirit striking weapons are more useful than the higher damage weapons.

Are there things I think could be better.. yes!
I would like to see the earth element used and complete the elemental chain
I wouldn't mind have seeing other caster types, 8 classes and only 2 use spells
The stat generator at the start is.... evil... yep! anything where you can watch the same stat get rolled 90% of the time shouldn't be used.

To finish:
I like this game, I think it's great and love how the difficulty works. It is not for everyone and it has flaws, but if you like dungeon crawlers and a bit of a challenge then get this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198422199704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 431, 'playtime_forever': 2575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2575, 'last_played': 1607413123}
review:
This is another Old school first person view dungeon crawler.

The Mazes are nicely made and planned, making exploring fun. But some of the mechanisms can be frustrating especially during trail and error time where everything require luck, but they did add a map autopath navigator to save us the trouble on repeating areas, so that puts the frustration on the minimum.

Story is a bit swallow in total but mysterious all the way. (Kinda like those "Mid-school" settings)

Overall game play is a bit short compared to some other similar titles, but with its multi-endings, they require players to at least repeat the game 3 times to get them all. I stopped at the 1st play through myself, because the 2nd run is exactly the same play except the divinity part and multi-ends. Though those who planned to do it can easily repeat the other 2 runs using the map auto-path, the maps you explored get carried over to the post game and 2nd run on wards as well as items and levels. So the repeat run should be a breeze and speedy.

In overall, this is a great game. Players who love dungeon crawlers can fully enjoy playing this game no doubt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039461996', 'num_games_owned': 1673, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2066, 'last_played': 1604596460}
review: Dobry Dungeon Crawler

author: {'steamid': '76561198039984325', 'num_games_owned': 2880, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1618197974}
review:
So, I REALLY like jank first person dungeon crawlers, and this game, among them, is very good.

Obviously, this is a genre for insane people, but for those insane people, you will love this.

Do you want to minmax the fuck out of your experience? If so, play this game today.

A lot of the negative reviews seem to be made by people that don't seem to realize that the life point system is there to encourage you to make multiple builds for different classes so you can swap out your people, and that the level cap is low precisely BECAUSE you're expected to class swap to get more skills, because if you don't, you'll only have two skill slots, which is, suffering.

Is this game perfect? God no, but for what it is, a game that's designed for making you feel like a fucking genius for cracking the code to how to play the game, I can recommend it. It's also more balanced than Elminage Gothic, so it's got that doing for it.

8 out of 10, this game is for people who are already used to the genre, and got their feet wet with something more accessible like Etrian Odyssey Untold.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073080354', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1293, 'last_played': 1697041913}

author: {'steamid': '76561198012807542', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1604089718}
review:
Game not reccomendable.
1) story average
2) gfx below average
3) sfx average
4) gameplay.... well first, it is what one would expect from an asia grinder rpg when it comes to exploring and fighting, nothing new, nothing special, just same good old... but the rest
- 90% of the game is not explained anywhere and you have to go out to the internet to find your answers, or try figuring out on your own
- there is no progression... you do the start, you do the tutorial mission and you go grinding for... no idea how long, ... the next step is slums but the lineage at the entrace is just lvl 11 and like undefeatable with a lvl 7 party (yah yah I know the stupid comments of "get gud" but there is no getting gud when there is nothing you can do but to select fight and defend and spell and then just watch)... so you go grind the same old beginner dungeon where anything between lvl 3 and 18 can spawn, so either you grind for an eternity or run, and if unlucky a lvl 5 mob will kill someone and when that someone hits 0 Lifepoints it is gone for good and the items with it

author: {'steamid': '76561198086213662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 7249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7249, 'last_played': 1600582779}
review:
I've been playing a fair amount of dungeon crawlers lately and after beating Demon Gaze 2 I wanted to give this a try. It's not a bad game but it is punishing in a way that I could not recommend this game to other players.

So what is good? Well, like Demon Gaze, Dungeon Traveler, etc. It's straight forward and to the point, make a team, here is some dungeons with monsters, hunt them down. The story is okay and essentially exists to facilitate you murdering special monsters galore to find a new area and begin anew. You can pick your classes, roll how you want, and bam you're in business.

Now all of that being good this game in every way playing it sabotages those good things in practice.
The way each class is built is that every one lacks key abilities you need to not get steam rolled later in the game. You can by most of the game with a decent traditional balance of characters but you get crushed hard mid-late game by status attacks, formation changes, and instant kill spells/attacks. You can fix this but it involves grinding each class to the level you need for the skill you want, changing to another class, level again for the skill you want etc. Your level gets cut in half everytime and exp is a slog if you aren't built for farming the two types of encounters that give decent exp.

The issue above gets compounded by loot farming in this game (which you need to do, do not use base stat gear, you will suffer for it) being a bad loop. Few pieces of gear are properly viable and you have to farm ambushes until you roll the items you want with stats you can use. Multiple this by six characters with 4-6 pieces of equipment each and welcome to hell. Added to this issue is that bonus stats on items are directly related to your level, so you need to grind then re-grind to pull good items to use. So if you are not over leveled you'll never draw gear with stats that are good and as stated earlier exp in this game is a drip feed so you're in for the long haul.

One of the biggest issues early on though is that the one unique system to this game is stupidly punishing for no relevant reason other than a small nod to the story. Characters have life points, they run out, they die forever. A lot of things in this game you 100% can not stop from happening until end game/post game with rebuilt characters that by pass a lot of the games cheap mechanics. Death is extremely expensive for most of the game, so that you can't afford it and treating without cash takes grinding battles with a key party member dead. So you either save like crazy to spare yourself despair or grind 30mins-2+ hours with weak substitutes to revive a dead character and heal life points without paying. Short and sweet there is a lot of suffering in this game that is not relevant to how well you play it.

I still beat it, got it 100% done and there is fun to be had once you have a properly built murder squad. The fact is though 90%-95% players will never get there and I can't say it's really worth it. What you endure to get the few fun story and monster fights is lopsided as can be. Unlike in Dungeon Travelers 2 where all builds are viable and you build how you want with some classes being shining stars. Here no one is amazing until you grind your fingers to the bone to build a workable team that does well consistently in a game you'll likely hate long before finishing. I only paid $5 for this and even then I'd say hit up a fast food place for more lasting enjoyment from a dollar menu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051482123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 3648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3614, 'last_played': 1600827328}
review:
The game is simply not balanced and broken all up and down its entire idea of gameplay.  It caters to a specific crowd.  I grew up playing Wizardy, Stonekeep, Bards Tale series, & Beholder.  Gameplay is visual crawl like Stonekeep, but Combat style like Wizardy/Bards Tale.  It was fun at first, but it got monotonous and started to drag on.  Your characters can easily die but you can also mitigate those.  However that is part of the rub as well.  Farming equipment through ambushes was novel at first but quickly becomes annoying due to the limit of the Moral meter something that is important in the game but winds up just being a gimmick just for added complexity.

Leveling is a Grind or at least I never found good exp farming spots so that might be on me.  Magic is joke in this game.  Your spell casters are weak and will never be able to out gun your Melee warriors to the point that they should have just made spells free to use.  Your Cleric can recovery magic but your Wizard cannot.  Ninja class is OP/Broken and Samurai are your Best general DPS unit.  I once took down a mini-boss (Prince mob for Forest) with the Carnage Back skill in round 1 once while it was able to kill multiple party members in other engagements around the same level.  How is that for balance and RNG goodness?

Also, even putting your Magic Users in the front lines as fodder for protection against critical and status affecting attacks is a viable strategy in this game.  Just imagine... your Samurai's, Fighters, and Knights all plotting an offensive strike behind your magic users holding up shields.  Did they not think about the mechanics here or were they just throwing ideas at the wall like spaghetti?

You can multiclass for skill farming too... but if you are going to multiclass magic users... make sure they are your last class chosen because your characters Max MP is cut in half each class change and will not grow upon level up unless your class is a magic user.  This is a huge let down and makes only the passive skills worth pursuing for Cleric/Mage  But if you do Dual Class a Mage/Cleric you can free up a slot for another Melee Character at least.

Some of you will like this game... but not most of you if I have the idea of this one pegged right.
The Mapping system in this game is well done though... You can fast travel to where you want to go, and just watch the game rush you there.  It does have a couple of flaws like in the forest where you can lose your direction and the map will not let you use it.  Nice way to arbitrarily kill a convenience feature there devs for no discernable reason other than to get that last laugh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138312932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 240, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1600658245}
review:
If you want a mind-numbingly boring grind-fest, this is for you. 

I suspect there is some good lore buried deep inside of this S**T game, but I can't be bothered to look for it anymore. This game is awfully balanced and requires endless grinding to progress in the story. I love the dungeon crawler style with the anime spin, but the game mechanics themselves are offensively bad. 

Enjoy hours of walking around in the same beginner's area while encountering a huge range of encounter levels that can either one-shot you or simply be a nearly endless horde of skeletons!
...Or go play a good dungeon crawler like Stonekeep or Anvil of Dawn. 

I sure hope the other NIS titles are better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967976610', 'num_games_owned': 1387, 'num_reviews': 181, 'playtime_forever': 2752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1624877835}
review:
Wait until under $5 (AU), I've owned this game originally on my PSVita (original release and refresh version, US account), at the end of the day it is more about wasting time then being an enjoyable rpg/dungeon crawling game.  Progression is behind a farming/luck wall, given that you'll be farming an area over and over to get enough xp/armour/weapons to be able to progress the story and hope you don't run into impossible battles at a lower level area. Unfortunately the equivalent of D&D/Ultima/Wizardry/Might & Magic are no longer being made in a decent form. (Most that are made are $$$ grabbing DLC farmers)

Beware of "Saviors of Sapphire Wings / Stranger of Sword City Revisited";(Revisited should be a free copy for original owners), very likely to be another money grab for older un-ported ex-console games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988040892', 'num_games_owned': 291, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1599958744}
review:
Now I've barely played the game at this point but there is a lot to like about it. First the art is amazing, everything seems to be voice acted (albeit in japanese) and the combat seems deep enough to be a challenge. It's an older RPG dungeon crawler where you move around a small map square by square, encounter enemies, level up and get stronger. I can tell you that most of these kind of RPG's are grindy. Not in a bad way if you like that kind of thing, mind you, but some people tend to like a more streamlined linear RPG where the story gives you enough XP to progress naturally. I like working for it so this game is up my alley.

My literal only nitpick about this game is that none of the audio options seems to actually do anything. I turn the audio totally off for the background music but it still plays at the same level constantly and the sound effects and voices are still at default despite the bar being turned to OFF. Annoying because I like to listen to podcasts while I play games but whatever. 

For as little as I paid for it ($3.99) I feel like I got a heck of a deal. I'd even say this is worth it for the 20 dollar price tag.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027063266', 'num_games_owned': 406, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1119, 'last_played': 1597543724}
review:
What can i say it mixes all the worst principles of NIS titles such as endless grinding to make progress, trash item rich world, and repeating the same area over and over again until your eyes bleed. With the absolute worst mechanics of a rogue lite like perma death for your hired npc's, paired with instant kill attacks with multiple hits and each hit can kill you. An absolutely nonsensical defensive stat availability, and lastly a very specific set of class abilities from multiclassing forever to get a character that wont instantly implode in any boss fight.. This game at most times is in fact a torture simulator.

The game is literally built on you taking characters you make and leveling them into oblivion to make them functional with incredibly slow xp gain outside very risky fights. every time you want to walk into a new zone, the amount you ground instantly becomes irrelevant as you need the gear from inside the new area to survive the new area. After you go through this process about 2-3 times and start permanently losing characters you have spent literal days in game time building up.

The defensive options are so stupid, its almost entirely based on evasion and hit, every non magic character basically has to rush 25 agi to hit anything even equipping + hit weapons on most classes will give you about a 30% hitrate. i have a character with 63 defense that takes less damage than my 79 defense character. And theres basically no way to preotect against magic damage until after its killed about 25 characters.

All in all its an RNG fest with terrible game mechanics that dont matchup to a fun experience. Normally with NIS i would power through because they have sometimes some very amazing stories like Disgai. but this game is almost devoid of any story.

review:
I'm addicted to this game because of the creative imerssion... imerseion... imerson.... (whatever), the team build is really fun and really fun to give backstory and personality to the characters, basically this game has a very minimalist narrative that leaves you with a lot of space to imagine and create.

The art is a total masterpiece its very repetitive and really short but each character is super well developed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051384139', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 4200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1106, 'last_played': 1590037237}
review:
Very solid RPG.  I like it much better than Elminage the Original.
Pro:  
Good art work (also customizable portraits).
Six member party with lots of options.
Interesting story.
The puzzels are mostly interesting and not ridiculously hard like some other games.
Multiple endings.
Con:
Translation is pretty bad.
Shop items does not respawn.
Some gears are hard to find.
Lots grinding.
Crits = instant death.
Some bosses are ridiculously hard.
Definitely worth a try especially on sale.

review:
Okay party based dungeon crawler.
Art style is outstanding with choices between more western or more eastern looking art styles.
The soundtracks and audio is pretty decent.
Gameplay can be a tedious with grinding and how slow crawlers play in general.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052351115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 2124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1633525092}
review:
>87h de jeu (offline). Pas fini encore la 1Ã¨re partie.

Dessins,ambiance,musique pas mal du tout je trouve.

Par contre: "difficultÃ©" totalement s-t-u-p-i-d-e. 
Dommage mais jeu vraiment trop frustrant.

Hyper alÃ©atoire avec la trÃ¨s grande majoritÃ© des boss qui ont 98% de chance de oneshot n'importe lequel de vos personnage Ã  chaque attaque quel que soit les stats/niveaux.....absurde et punitif .
Sans compter la mort permanente des persos crÃ©Ã©s si on ne les envois pas 10h Ã  l'hopital dÃ¨s que KO.
Ce qui vous met vite au chÃ´mage faute d'Ã©quipe sur pied.
Ceci pour masquer un manque d'imagination des DEV? Je n'appel pas "Ã§a" difficile, juste mal Ã©quilibrÃ©/testÃ©.

A rÃ©server pour du casual gaming et que pour les grooos amateurs de jeux de rÃ´le tour par tour.
A jouer 20 /30 mn pas plus Ã  chaque fois puisque Ã  999% c'est du grind d'XP et de matÃ©riel sinon impossible de gagner.

Je vais le terminer (aprÃ¨s sans doute 15h de grind d'exp en plus...) mais c'est dommage la difficultÃ© doit Ãªtre revue.

Peut Ãªtre la 2e version amÃ©liorÃ©e sortie en 2e temps sur Vita corrige ces problÃ¨me? 
Aucune idÃ©e, les joueurs PC ont Ã©tÃ© oubliÃ©s pour cette version corrigÃ©e...

author: {'steamid': '76561198018559118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5934, 'last_played': 1583104299}
review: This game is hard, like sometimes really hard if you do not want anyone to die at all. But it is fun and don't be afraid to hospitalize your party, just make an additional set of temporary party members and you'll do good. Also, a good tank is the key to most battles. Overal I'd say its a good dungeon crawler so if you enjoy the genre, you should get this. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198131086843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 609, 'last_played': 1575341590}
review: Took me awhile to figure out why I wasn't a fan of this game.  It heavily pushes towards grinding, but limits recovery during grinding drastically

author: {'steamid': '76561198215857911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1582191829}
review: I felt the controls of this game were ment for a console and thus were rather janky for a pc user. The art style is amazing and really apreciate the effort of it. However thats where it ends. The game sets itself as a dnd in VN style which I like but the fight mechanics are confusing and you must confirm EVERYTHING EVERY TIME. And thus I did not finish the game due to such an annoying mechanic that I cannot stand the least.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112838066', 'num_games_owned': 1428, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 3018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3018, 'last_played': 1580326572}
review:
Let me start by saying I am absolutely in love with this game despite all its massive flaws and infuriating dificulty wall (because calling it a curve or even a cliff did not feel quite right).

I was originally planning to recommend it despite those flaws and to try and explain them/how to best deal with them... But then I found out there exists an updated re-release of this game that fixes most of my issues with the game, fixes the difficulty issues and adds a lot of new content; But unfortunately that re-release is a PSvita exclusive, with seemingly no plans for it to ever get a PC release.

I'd honestly just say to wait for a possible PC release of it, even if it never comes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198268108561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1579367991}
review:
Pros:
+Art and visuals
+Custom Character feature
+Dungeon Crawling mechanics

Cons:
-Dialogue (very bland, and it goes on forever. Could easily shrink two paragraphs of dialogue into two meaningful sentences)
-UI (combat options are clunky compared to others of this genre (especially Shin Megami Tensei), and the message bar is on top of the screen, so you're either reading text, or looking at numbers, and not both)

After about an hour of boredom(Dialogue)/frustration(from UI), I got a refund and played SMT4 instead. This has great potential, but needs a QoL update.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961131873', 'num_games_owned': 1029, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 1714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1632, 'last_played': 1601967284}
review:
Good, solid blobber.  I didn't think I liked these kind of games any more but I keep getting drawn back to this whenever I have the urge just to level up a little and get a little farther.

What's different about this game?

[list][*]"Lineages"
The purpose of the game is to hunt "lineages", meaning big, unique monsters.*  The twist here is that each lineage has its own little story and place in the world, which means you aren't just wandering around hoping one will appear.  Some live in certain places, some can be lured out with the use of a certain item, and, yes, some [i]do[/i] just wander around certain areas as random encounters.  As a result, the game feels more like a hunt than an exercise in filling in the maps.

* Not to be confused with the English word lineage.  This has nothing to do with genealogy.

[*] Ambushes.

You can set up your own ambushes to get great loot.  In every dungeon, there are opportunities to hunt 'transporters', special enemies that carry treasure chests.  Each chest will carry an item of a certain type and quality that you can see before starting the fight, so you might hide and wait for an enemy carrying a Gold chest with Armor in it.  Then you have to beat the 'transporter' in a short time or they will escape with the loot.  This is a fun time sink for building up your party's gear, and finding new and more lucrative ambush spots is a satisfying form of progress.

[*] The Revive/Recover system and fluid party builds.

Instead of a single set party, you will have a "stable" of up to 16 characters.  When a character is downed, they don't just stand up again at the end of a fight, or get rezzed at the temple for a few gold pieces.  Instead, you take them back to base for a long recovery period, forcing you to use alternate characters in the meantime.  This sounds punishing, but it actually makes things more fun as it gives you incentive and opportunity to mix up your party composition.  This is made even more interesting by having a party size of only 6, but 8 character classes.  Is a Ninja a good substitute for a Dancer?  Because my Dancer got knocked out.  What if my Fighter and my Samurai got knocked out so I have to substitute a Knight and a Ranger on my front line for a while instead?  Will that work?  It's neat.

[*] Character customization.

Lastly, the game has a built-in function to import your own .png files to use for your party.  No need to use elaborate mods or follow a guide to hack the file system, just add your images.  For a customization hound like me this really adds to my attachment to the party.[/list]
I got the game on sale for $9 and have about 30 hours so far.  (I am [b]far[/b] from finished.)  I'd say this is easily worth full price $20, and on sale it's a very good investment.  It won't completely blow your mind but again is a good solid game with some nice new features to liven up the classic blobber gameplay.  Do yourself a favor and grab it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967471651', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 32072, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 555, 'last_played': 1702570931}
review:
Awesome game made for fans of the genre as it's quite challenging with no hand-holding at all.

The basic gameplay is you create a team of 6 adventurers who set out to explore a mostly open ended series of dungeons teeming with all sorts of secrets and nasties, alongside some unique and interesting gameplay mechanics such as your characters setting up ambushes for the enemies. Your team can be changed at any time as you maintain a retinue of up 12 characters. 

There's lots of little tools and features in the game to make dungeon exploration and combat more pleasant. The dungeon is automapped and also features a quick move system where you simply select a point on the map and can have your party start hauling arse over there. Combat also features the ability to speed through a round or to auto-repeat the previous turn's actions, including in between battles.

Character creation is interesting with a whole lot of room for creativity. Your character can swap classes (of which there are 8) up to 6 times letting him mix and match skills from whatever classes you want. A ranger can do some strong ranged damage from the backrow to single enemies. A samurai can slash a whole group at once. Combine them together and you have a samuanger attacking everybody at once from the backrow. New characters you create during your adventure will also start at a level proportional to your hero instead of 0, so therer's no real concern about creating a screwed up character. Send them to the executioner and bring in the new recruit!

The game features a pseudo-permadeath system that provides real consequences. Characters have up to 3 hearts. When they die they lose one heart and need to be revived at town. You can either pay more than than you have for this to be done instantly or wait for a certain amount of 'time' which is just battles. You can then restore that character's hearts, after they revive, for *far* more money than you have to have it happen instantly, or let them rest to restore them over time for, similarly, way more time. If they die when they have only 1 heart then pseudo-permadeath becomes simply permadeath. Your main character is the exception to this who can die as much as you like with no risk of permadeath or removal from the party - the chosen and all that.

The system lets you ensure you never *have* to face a perma-death, but it makes failure in combat have much greater consequences than the typical 'use fly back to town item' + 'heal team for a pittance' + 'go back stronger than ever' pattern. 

If you enjoy wizardry-like games, you'll probably love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081711959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1578769928}
review:
I posted a fairly thorough review of the game and steam some how lost it, and I don't feel like re-writing that mess..

I want to preface this review with stating that I am a fan of first person dungeon crawler games, dating back to the 80's and 90's. Love the genre.. that being said....

 Basically I felt this game tried to do some new things for the genre and they fell flat of what could have been achieved. Also I didn't like the artwork style clashes, and I realize you can import portraits as well and that was cool.

 Ambushing is a boring slog, and serves as the main way of getting gear improvements. It is boring. You know it is boring now. That is all.

 Character creation is worse than un-modded Wizardry VI, (I didn't feel that was too bad but many did), and there is even a guide here on steam that talks you through setting up an auto-roller program to roll your characters for you. It's that intensely boring and mind-numbing. You can pick from a list of "talents" to kind of individualize characters but it's typically "safe" to just choose the talent that gives you a few more bonus points to allocate to your stats. Age helps you with the minimum points you'd get on character creation, the higher the age of the character, the better bonus point roll you receive, with the trade off that you get less "hearts" or "lives". If a character dies, a heart is removed from them, it can regenerate over time, but once they lose all their hearts they are permanently gone. Perma-death does not bother me, but this might be a stop point for many, so be aware it is possible.

 The lore is there, but it's bad. Real bad. And I never at any point found myself caring about any NPC in any way shape or form, at all. The translation is bad, but not as bad as say Elminage Original (which I found many times more entertaining than this game btw), and I also did not care for the music either. This game just was not exciting for me, and really didn't motivate me to find out what happens next.. it just.. blegh.. blandly hobbled along for the short time I played it.

 I really don't feel like re-writing everything I originally wrote about this game, so I'll just end this with saying Stranger of Sword City is an extremely boring experiment of sorts. It tried to do new things, which I can appreciate, but it just failed incredibly at getting me interested in it. It is sad because I wanted find something I could enjoy about it, but just couldn't get myself invested in it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133711616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 4642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3281, 'last_played': 1589858173}
review:
this game is unpolished gem.
good music, cool art and design.
unexpectedly this game have a very good dark and gloomy story despite all of the main casts is high-schooler.
the only part drag down this game is actually the gameplay. gameplay is unique and fun but it's too grindy and waste too much time which make you ultimately just skipping all fights for the sake of quick grind. there is a random overpowered encountered which insta-kill you if you are not careful while skipping fights. horrible and punishing level design.

overall this game is good but if you don't like DRPG game you should never buy this. you won't survive the grind.

my personal favorite. one of the few series which i love to buy if there is any sequel of it.

edit : looks like there is a lot better version on ps vita. buy vita version instead if you have the console
more edit : revisited version bundled with savior of sapphire wings available on steam. go get that instead

author: {'steamid': '76561198052234570', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1277, 'last_played': 1578328563}
review:
The game has a great visual design, interesting monsterdesigns and overall fun dungeon layout. I really enjoyed playing it until now.

It's just one minor thing that sucked the fun out of it for me: the way the permadeath is handled in this game. Aside from very few items that can revive your characters, each death that happens will lose you a lot of real world time. For a character to revive and recover you have to fight 50+ fights without him/her. And you can only save outside the dungeon, so resetting inside the dungeon is impossible without losing progress.
Pair that with the fact that some enemies can get critical hits that just outright kill a character without a check for HP or defence, you feel like you're constantly at the mercy of a dieroll to lose an hour or more of your time with each fight.

Yes, not all enemies can instakill you, and there are ways to avoid it, but those are very roundabout (choosing a trait at character-creation, would mean you ignore all other ones; or casting a divinity each turn in fights with enemies that might crit you, meaning a) you can't use any other divinity and b) you'd have to look up first which enemies can crit you or learn by trial-and-error).

It's really a very solid game; I had fun playing it. It's a pity this single mechanic really ruins it.

review:
This is another Classic Dungeon Crawler in the same vein of the classic Wizardry franchise. If you enjoy a good dungeon crawler this seems to be right up your ally. (ill be playing more and updating if need be) However know that it is a CLASSIC dungeon crawler. All the good and bad there in. Some of these other reviews show that they have not played a dungeon crawler before. 

if you like dungeon crawlers you will likely enjoy this. If you dont, you wont.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047166944', 'num_games_owned': 844, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1562541705}
review:
This game is one for the old school among us, beautiful artwork combined with typical turn based dungeon crawler with some new after battle twists, in short it is Etrian Odasey with extra bits.

The after battle twist is a risk reward system that can send you running back to base camp to heal up or continue on like normal. The reason is the reward chest that is trapped and how you open it can determine what you will be doing next, open it without a care and your party may end up all poisoned and if you forgot to pack antidotes or are too cheep then back to base if you can reach it that is.  Pay attention and you open the chest but you won't know what types of weapons nor can you use them until they are identified, that will depend on your INT factor as well as skills on your party.

Saving the game is done at the base, your main character upgrade is a choice that will determine your story faction.

But one thing that is missing is this game is a lesser version of the Playstation Vita copy which has more artwork as well as character classes.

The game does well enough on its own in that you will grind and make your way to the end, rush and you will die, make mistakes, fight bosses while under leveled and cry the game is too hard.
