author: {'steamid': '76561197993895864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1577501452}
review:
The positive reviews on this are frankly nonsense, this game is legit awful.

For a game that is so UI heavy, the UI is beyond terrible.  At one point I thought I had deleted a character with a button press, only to realize later that it was hidden behind some other obscure menu.  The UI/menus are scatterbrained and the game has you do tedious things in various nested menus again and again.

The game balance is dreadfully bad, the first zone has enemies that one shot your party members, which puts them out of commission for like an hour of real world time, forcing you to use other newly created members at level 1 with no items instead and if they die one to many times then its perma death.  The item store in town does not replenish items you need.. (like equipment for new members! and consumables for healing!) and you definitely need them because the game demands you grind your butt off in the first zone!  Literally I spent hours on the first quest and made what seemed to be zero progress, as it wanted me to 'hunt' a creature that was nowhere to be found, instead my heal items would get cursed after one use, and then my party members would get one shotted by regular mobs.  After about the 12th time of going back to town I decided I had had enough of this garbage.

It seems to me the only good thing about this game is the VO, and the music was alright, everything else was bad, to nonexistent, and by nonexistent I mean the graphics/art.  Battles are a joke both visually and mechanically.  There is no animation to speak of, its just 2d cards, and basic texture effects, most of the time you can't even tell what is going because it is so undeveloped visually.  Mechanically it was not fun, and extremely tedious, basically a simple AI could play this game because there was no real strategy, only grinding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026673593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 2449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1666153724}
review: It's more approachable and less inscrutable than some other games in this sub-genre, but Sword City won't let you forget it's still a dungeon crawler. Expect a lot of grind, a lot of traps, and a whoooole lot of party wipes on surprise attacks (and thus a lot of redundant backup characters). Class change is simple & fairly painless, but you're expected to focus a character's overall build rather than try to god-mode all the classes into one. the morale/divinity system opens up a number of super useful options for fights, but it's also tied into a weird faction system that's basically "choose your fantasy girlfriend." All in all, it's a fine entry to the field.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037888592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1490935687}
review: This game is hard. Permadeath is a thing, leveling and exploring is a chore. Those things don't make the ge bad, but I had a hard time enjoying it personally. I so desperately want to enjoy this title because I love the concept and customization available but I can't get far enough in to really like it. If you want a game with a challenge and like the jrpg aesthetic, give it a shot. But I personally can't recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061178718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 12695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7321, 'last_played': 1656910392}
review:
If you are new to this game, PLEASE press f1 in game and read the manual. This is a very complex RPG with multiple mechanics that function somewhat differently than other RPGs. it takes time to learn how to play this game and even more time to master this game's mechanics. 

In my opinion, this is one of the most optimized RPGs ever. The fast apply makes grinding quick and fun! Fast apply allows you to input all your character attacks/commands and the game plays the turn out lightning quick. This cuts down on wasted time on trash mobs dying and other repetitive animations that you have to sit through in other RPGs. Grinding doesn't feel the slightest bit tedious because you want to ambush to get better loot and you can skip all animations to get right down to the numbers. This is a great experience for people who want to farm for stronger loot and utilize the ability to re-roll unique items (unique items can be found one time only and re-rolled for better stast) for better stats is awesome. This game also has some of the best character, and enemy portrait art/images I have ever seen in a video game. There were some enemies that were re-colors of other enemies, but this is used sparingly. The bosses in this game have the coolest portraits and that helps to immerse the player in the fantasy world of this game. You can even upload your own .png files to use as your character's portrait art! 

There are also multiple endings/story pathes, a New game+ (NG+) mode  and a difficult post game area that will keep you grinding to make your characters even stronger! 

In my opinion: This game has the best RPG quality of life mechanics ever! This game feels much better than Etrian Odyssey! (and I love the Etrian odyssey series...that WAS my favorite dungeon crawler till I played this game.)

Stranger of Sword City is the best turn-based dungeon crawler RPG I have ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094314206', 'num_games_owned': 1333, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 2346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1757, 'last_played': 1645414448}
review:
Nothing worse than a grindy game that only allows saving at distant intervals (only when you get back to base), that also crashes deep into outings.  It's really something in this kind of game to get some really good items, be on the way back, and then suddenly watch the window disappear along with a half hour of gameplay.

Thumbs down for bad save system + unstable game.

Side note to the devs: I know you're going for the retro feel of the old Wizardry games, the Western versions of which I played in my youth, and I really appreciate what you're shooting for here.  But even the Wizardry games moved on from that abominable save system in, what, Wizardry 5 or 6?  Bad save system = bad UI and player experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069180082', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1545075770}
review: i mean if you enjoy grinding for a weapon that actually does more then 10 (Base) damage, choose between 3 leaders to give some shit to (it really does not matter because you have to give them to some other person), getting lost in mazes, and finding bosses with cryptic summoning requirements, then sure, this is a good game for you, unless you cheat (which is confusing as fuck for this game engine, also yeah yeah cHeAtEr cHeAtEr!!!!), always have a good party with you, and you don't even have to find that perfect member, because you can make them yourself (i guess they just have someone with those SPECIFIC requirements hanging around.) Weird (and maybe unique system?) is the *Ambush* feature which is as it says, Ambush monsters and such for a chance to get a (really bad) chest with a (small) chance to get decent gear. thats really are there is with this, (also pirating this game fucks with the save system so dont do that, either buy it and play it or dont)

author: {'steamid': '76561198130948719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1571276062}
review:
A mild thumbs-up for doing â€œBlobberâ€ RPG mechanics well, though the overall game will not hold my interest to completion due to weak worldbuilding and narrative design.

The engine is stable and smooth. The art style isnâ€™t exceptional, but gets the job done. The interface is easy to navigate and works very well with a controller (even better than mouse + keyboard, which I usually prefer). The base RPG mechanics will be familiar to those who played the old Wizardry series. Progression is steady with enough challenge to require strategic decision making, but without being so hard that it gets frustrating. There are mechanics available to recover from your failures; healing someone who has fallen in battle is time-consuming and expensive, but it can be done. It's also easy to replace fallen comrades with entirely new characters. The main character cannot die permanently, but if the entire party is wiped out, you must revert to a previous save.

The game mechanics are good, but the story is contrived, dry and thin, and thereâ€™s no good reason for it to be so 40 years after the first Wizardry game was released. You're a "Chosen One" / Stranger who has appeared in Sword City, a mashup of generic fantasy and steampunk, after a real-world plane crash. It seems like many victims of mass disasters appear here, as there is also a cruise ship one of the three gameâ€™s factions is using as a base. As someone from the real world, you're basically super-human. It's your job to hunt "LIneage Types" (bosses) to loot Blood Crystals that you use give to faction leaders to unlock meta powers like group healing over time. Your eventual goal is to get back to your world.

Sword City has Humans, a sort of Elf, Dwarves, cat people and a race whose name I forget but whose members looks like Link from the Zelda series. It has medieval tech from European and Japanese cultures, as well as Steampunk elements you only encounter during the meta-story; there are no guns or machines you can use while adventuring. And there's generic magic, mostly healing and elemental-type spells.

The monsters you fight are not logically cohesive; the first level (called a "labyrinth" in the game) is a desert space with ruined stone buildings and a stone dungeon underneath, in which you fight goblins that look like rats, hydras, flying insects, blobby type things, sprite-looking things with weird names like "Fitzgerald" (I forget the exact name, but there were three of them, three "Fitzgeralds"). And the occasional boss, I mean, â€œLineage Typeâ€. I assume this is a poor translation of something that makes sense in Japanese. Some of these â€œtypesâ€ have mini-quest storylines attached to them, and some seem randomly placed so you have enough bosses to fight to collect the necessary blood crystals.

One of your gear slots is "Underwear". That deserves its own bullet point for weirdness. It's not done in a tawdry way; it's just one of a very small number of slots for armor that affects your stats. You have no foot slot, no hand slot, no leg slot, just armor, helmet and...underwear. And it's not a poor translation, as there are also references to "undies". They really decided to have a slot called "Underwear".

The limited NPC dialogue is anachronistic, excessively modern and full of slang, which distracts from any sense of place the rest of the environment might give. Major characters speak like teenagers; one even mentions "high school". In some dialogues, they completely break the 4th wall and refer to the "game" or to a specific mechanic or stat. The dialogue is also not skippable, and it goes on and on and ON, frequently using 30 lines of dialogue (each requiring a button press, visual-novel style) to express a concept that could have been done in 5.

I was entertained for a few hours while I was learning the mechanics, but the lack of any meaningful story means Iâ€™ll be quitting early and moving on to the next game. 50+ hours of grinding just to finish the game with no emotional payoff for success isnâ€™t worth the time investment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011081947', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1650001409}
review:
Okay.  Hey, you, person thinking about buying this or any other "Japanese Style" game.

Stop.

If you know what I mean by "Japanese Style" game and are still 100% thrilled about buying this game, go ahead you sick, masochistic bastard.  If you don't know what I mean then listen up.  I don't know if you know this but Japan is kind of...  weird.  When the Japanese make a game they have one of four concepts in mind:  Fighting Game, Rhythm Game, Racing Game, or Masochistic Sisyphean Oh-God-Why Grinding Game.

This game is the last type.

For the uninitiated, let me break down what that actually means in terms of game play.  Basically what it comes down to is, "Did you just donkey fuck that fight?"  What I mean to say is once you've managed to finish a fight, do you feel as though you just watched a poor, misguided girl (the enemies) get mounted and absolutely fucked by a donkey (your party)?  And I mean thoroughly ruined.  Like, you feel bad inside just a teeny bit now after the fact...  About a group of randomly generated monsters.  If your answer is anything less than a good donkey fucking, stop.  Do not proceed further.  You aren't strong enough.  Just around the next corner is a surprise boss fight that will absolutely destroy you.  Go back and grind again until said fight is 100% straight out of some back alley Tiajuana night club and a tinge of guilt is once again your favorite traveling buddy.  Go back to town, heal, stock up, buy some stuff and keep on grinding.  It doesn't matter if it's a boss fight, random fight, scripted whatever... If you so much as pause for one moment, you haven't grinded enough.

"That sounds tedius, Llama!  Who would ever make a game like that?  That doesn't sound like fun at all!" said the guy who has never seen a Nippon Ichi game.

Alright look, I'm not trying to say this game isn't good or you shouldn't buy it.  I just want you to understand that games like these take a certain amount of determination and perhaps a modicum of self-loathing if you want to get the most out of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970625493', 'num_games_owned': 1484, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 2243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2217, 'last_played': 1567472608}
review:
Some unfortunate design decisions keep this from being a good game. Not only does this game not respect your time, it is designed to waste it.

On the positive, I love the art style - the character and enemy designs are simply gorgeous, and the backgrounds are often very pretty as well. The premise is interesting, and I like the gameplay structure of exploring labyrinths, finding bosses, and defeating those bosses to progress and level up. The class system is very versatile, and the turn-based combat can be pretty fun.

On the downside, the game is punishing - not hard, just punishing. When a character gets knocked out in battle, they die and lose a life point. You can resurrect them back in town, but this takes about an hour of in-game dungeon exploring during which the character will be unavailable - when creating characters at the beginning, you better make a second copy of each character because you'll need it. Of course your secondary backup character will be lower level, but it's better than nothing. But when the character is finally resurrected, they'll still be down a life point, and characters only have 1-3 life points - when they lose their last life point, they're dead for good and cannot be brought back. You can recover a life point, but this takes about 4-7 hours of in game dungeon exploring, during which time that character is unavailable. So when a character gets knocked out, not only do you need to bring them back to town, but then you have to do without them for the next 5-7 hours of combat. If multiple characters get knocked out, you're then facing the choice of re-loading and losing however much progress you've made since then or spending 5-7 hours with a weak backup party grinding for loot and levels.

You'd figure that you could just play defensively and avoid character death, but the game doesn't work that way. The fight difficulty is like an EKG - flat lines followed by huge spikes. Standard enemy encounters will be trivially easy, with you beating several enemies without taking any damage. Then you encounter a boss, and the boss attacks 2-3 times a turn and can 2-shot any of your characters - if the boss hits the same character twice in one turn, they're dead. Later in the game enemies and bosses get one-hit-kills which will one-shot any character if the attack connects, and even party-wide auto-kill attacks.

Even among the standard enemy encounters, the game loves to occasionally throw enemies at you that are twice the level of everything else and will destroy you. A dungeon will be full of level 10-14 enemies that are trivial to defeat - the game features a "repeat last attack orders" button and a "fast forward to end of combat" button for a reason - but occasionally you'll encounter level 20 enemies. Sometimes these enemies look different, so that you'll notice, and other times they'll look exactly the same - the same exact Orcs that you've been killing without a second thought, except these will instead kill you. Better check the level of the enemy in each and every combat before you begin.

Unfortunately, levels sometimes mean nothing. As level 4-5 characters you will be killing level 10-14 enemies without taking a scratch. Then you'll come across a level 11 enemy in that same dungeon that has 10 times the armor and deals 10 times the damage of the other level 10 enemies. Only trial and error will tell you if this new level 11 enemy is as weak as all the other level 11 enemies or as strong as a boss and will 2-shot any of your characters or AoE the whole party for 1/3 of their health.

The class system is backwards, in that once you change out of a class you stop earning levels in that class, so a character you want to end up as a wizard should start as a cleric (or even a knight or dancer).

You'll want to min-max your characters from the very beginning, making your party 40 years old and your main character 60 years old for 3 and 6 extra stat points from the start (equivalent to 3-6 extra levels), and hitting the re-roll button over and over and over again to get 2-3 extra stat points. But even doing that, and putting points into Vitality for extra health, you characters will die to bosses, and you'll end up having to grind while they recover or grind to out-level and out-gear the content. And this was on the "Beginner" difficulty - I don't even want to know what "Normal" is like.

And the gear - your main way of increasing your strength - is random. It's random both in terms of what equipment you get - a ton of thrown weapons and magic wands when you want melee weapons, cloth armor when you want plate mail - and what quality - will that chest of swords contain broadswords or broken knives? And getting gear requires going into a dungeon, going to specific ambush sites, ambushing enemies to get loot, then leaving the dungeon and repeating. To get stronger, you have to grind for gear and hope to get lucky.

Etrian Odyssey handles these systems in a much better way. Knocked out characters have to be carried back to town leaving the party weak and vulnerable, but then you can revive them without having to waste hours grinding while they recover. When you multi-class, you can gain new skills in either class at each new level, without having to leave your original class behind. Enemies scale linearly without huge spikes - you know when you go to a new level that enemies will be harder, but they won't be impossibly hard. Every fight is challenging, you don't just auto-pilot your way through standard enemy encounters until you've progressed well beyond them. The bosses and mini-bosses are clearly marked so there's no surprise like one on-level enemy in a dungeon being 10 times stronger than all the others. And each new enemy you slay gives you materials to craft new equipment, taking the randomness out of character progression and getting new loot.

So unless you enjoy spending hours grinding for gear while your characters recover, pass on this game - as gorgeous as the character designs are - and play something else that isn't designed to waste your time.

review: Stranger of Sword City seems like a decent dungeon crawl. The game feels retro but in a good way. Overall I dont have a lot to say about this one, but if you think you may be down for a 2D dungeon crawl Stranger of Sword City seems like a it has a decent chance of being what you are looking for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006879453', 'num_games_owned': 1721, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 6687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6686, 'last_played': 1568901271}
review:
[h1] Stranger of Sword City - A Return to Hard Core Dungeon Crawling[/h1]

[b]Stranger of Sword City has quickly become one of my favourite dungeon crawlers of all time thanks to its gorgeous art, turn-based JRPG battles and a large variety of customization with lots of different classes and the ability to class change and mix-and-match.[/b]

Make no mistake, Stranger of Sword City is not without its faults. But to me the many great points the game has far outweight the bad. Lets quickly go over some of the major points that may cause heart ache for some, and the points that made me keep playing the game until the very, very, very end despite its faults.

[list]
 [*] The game is very unforgiving, to a ridiculous extent.
 [*] There is a big focus on loot, tons of ways to equip your cast.
 [*] Ambushing enemies rewards you with unique and powerful weapons and armor.
 [*] Grinding is necessary for later dungeons, especially post-game.
 [*] The story is interesting and doesn't pull any punches.
 [*] Multiple endings depending on your choices and Divinity-tree.
[/list]

Stranger of Sword City is a tough game, it doesn't hold your hand and is not afraid to punish you if you make a bad decision. There is perma-death, even on the easiest difficulty level so careful thinking and caution are essential for survival.

Your characters will have a set number of hearts depending on what age you assign them in the character creation. The older the character, the more skillpoints you get to assign, but in return your hearts will be lower. Each time your character falls on the battlefield they will lose a heart. Run out of hearts, and you lose that character forever. The only exception is your player-character who will always stick with you no matter what, and as such I recommend you put them in the front-line as either a tank or a damage dealer.

You can revive characters from death, and replenish their hearts at the guild headquarters. However this process takes lots of time, or tons of cash if you use the instant recovery and is not to be recommended. There are also a few items that can restore hearts, but they are extremely rare and difficult to acquire. All in all, I recommend you save often and play very cautiously. Also I do not recommend creating a character with less than two hearts, since a single death will wipe that character from existence, and there are a few insta-kill moves that bosses and end-game enemies like throwing out.

Luckily, not everything is quite so grim and you do have the power of the goddesses to aid you in these tough times.

As you progress through the game and acquire more and more Blood Crystals from bosses, you can hand these in to any of the three deities and they will reward you with powerful abilities. The Divinity skill tree lets you pick abilities that will best suit your needs. Divinities are very powerful special moves that do not take up a turn to use (with the exception of Charge attacks), and can be used at the start of each turn in addition to your normal skills. Divinity moves cost Morale to perform, which can be gained from fighting enemies normally. Who you choose to give crystals to affects the overall story too, and as such the ending, so think carefully before you make your offerings.

Finally, the art direction deserves a mention as my favourite thing about this entire game.

The character portraits and enemies are absolutely beautifully drawn, and the game lets you pick any character portrait you want without any bearing on your class, so feel free to look through the huge assortment of artstyles and character designs and pick your favourites. The bosses is where the artist shows off their true skill though. The foul beasts you encounter are not just intimidating, but captivating and memorable at the same time. The overall asthetic is dark, unsetteling, almost H.P. Lovecraftian in a way, and it fits the game's hardcore approach to dungeon crawling perfectly.



In conclusion, Stranger of Sword City is a game dear to my heart and I strongly recommend it to those who enjoy a difficult game where caution is a necessity and you need to take your time and think your options through carefully.

Strategy is a must, and you should not be afraid to experiment and try out new things when you run into problems. Often times a seemingly impossible boss battle can be beaten at your level, but you have to try a different approach. However since your characters level up and powerful loot can be gained from ambush battles, you can usually grind your way to greatness and simply power-through difficult encounters. Drop rates are low and leveling takes a long time later on, so I think the game does not recommend this idea, and rather expects you to try different classes and strategies instead, but near the end of the game some battles are so difficult that grinding loot is less of a choice and more of a requirement.

This balance between strategic choice and simple stat-checks is not an easy one to strike, and Stranger of Sword City does struggle with it a bit. But all in all I think it does a very good job at everything it sets out to do, and it has quickly become one of my favourites.



[b]TLDR:[/b] [strike] The Dark Souls of Dungeon Crawlers[/strike]

author: {'steamid': '76561198257696182', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 3881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3881, 'last_played': 1566934748}
review:
Text or Action
â˜ Visual novel
â˜ Don't be in a TL:DR mood while playing
â˜ Cutscenes are frequent, long and occasionally annoying
â˜‘ Strikes a good balance between plot and gameplay
â˜ Plot is mostly an excuse to fight
â˜ Straight to the action

SoSC contains a lot more plot than most blobbers, and it's actually pretty decent.  There are some relevant choices to be made as well, which affect the ending.

Difficulty
â˜ Final Fight 3
â˜ Typically on mental cruise control with occasional stop and consider moments
â˜ Planning ahead a bit is encouraged to do well
â˜‘ Grind hard or lose harder
â˜ Saga Frontier

It's modeled after Wizardry, so expect to grind.  Grind intelligently (ambush in the correct areas), otherwise be frustrated.  The game uses a lot of modern conveniences (easy access map, auto move and quick combat) to speed things along.

System issues
â˜ This shit should never have left beta
â˜ I performed the controller/keyboard toss over data loss
â˜ Crashed occasionally but nothing too major
â˜ Odd buggy quest here and there
â˜‘ All looked great

Storyline
â˜ Old gold box games have more story
â˜ Confusing or utterly ridiculous, possibly poorly translated
â˜ Fit for grade school kids
â˜ Lighthearted yet interesting 
â˜‘ Adult and/or dark in nature, captivating
â˜ Gripping, hard-to-predict plot twists

Immersion
â˜ Thinking about playing online poker instead
â˜ Not terrible, but a poor design mechanic is interfering with my enjoyment
â˜ I thought about plot or my next move while away
â˜‘ Just ONE more turn
â˜ I'll sleep when I'm dead

I'd been looking for a Wizardry-clone-type game that's similar to Wizardry - Tales of the Forsaken Land (PS2) and this comes pretty darn close.  SoSC is similar to Etrian Odyssey as well.  Class and skill system made me feel like my time spent grinding made a huge difference.  I love the atmosphere.  The dungeons are all beautiful, and I especially liked the haunted town.  SoSC is definitely one of the better party blobbers out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021895842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 757, 'last_played': 1566822385}
review:
Very good dip back into a very old style CRPG not seen much these days. Reminds me of the original Bard's Tale and Wizardry games, except we get an in-game map that saves on graph paper abuse. The game play is trickier than it looks on the surface. Party roles, placement, and making use of the ambush system are important keys. Pay attention to the levels of enemies and beware of gear with weakness on it. Having a character in full level encounter one of the low level magic users who can cast fire magic is a great way to lose a life point.

Having to recover injured characters with a partial party or rotating membership can be a bit painful, but you can compensate for it quite a bit just by choosing two weak maps and alternating between them to respawn the fixed encounters. Also realizing that the shop sold gear is mostly not worth purchasing, so you're best saving up your money for consumables, especially things that rez a fallen party member. If you are someone with super limited playtime you may dislike the game just due to the required grind at each new map to gear up before progressing the storyline, but if it's a game style you miss from your youth, you will find a lot of fun to be had here. The ability to class change and stack new abilities into the same character is a lot of fun too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008195723', 'num_games_owned': 980, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1968, 'last_played': 1572433006}
review: The game runs like a dungeon crawler. Obviously. I'd recommend other crawlers over this really. Story is okay though. So overall I'd probably give it an 8/10 and that's probably because I'm a fan of crawlers. Getting unique(legendary) items and upgrading them can be a hassle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143712190', 'num_games_owned': 634, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 852, 'last_played': 1693401675}
review:
The game could use better explanation of certain things such as what stats, skills, attributes/enchantments, etc. exactly do, because some of them are either vague or downright not explained at all. In addition to that, money's pretty useless outside class changing. Most, if not all of your gears and items will come from ambush points because Gillius is a pretty lazy shopkeeper and doesn't restock nor add in new items and gears to his shop. I think it also costs money to revive(?) party members who still have lifepoints left, but I didn't bother with that because I opted for the increased starting stats in exchange for only having one lifepoint for all party members since I'd rather be careful and avoid them dying in the first place, or just reloading if they do die of instead losing out on those additional early stat points. 
Story's pretty alright, got that SMT vibes to it, with the 3 alignments and all that. 
Graphics/art is alright too, but pretty inconsistent. Choosing the portrait for your MC and party members and you already see the different artstyles, which is pretty jarring. I mean it's great that you have choices, but at least make them blend to the game. Soundtrack does its job, I've already associated certain music to certain things/areas/situations, which is what the soundtrack's supposed to do, but it's nothing phenomenal.
Gameplay's great, I like dungeon crawlers and planning out your party members' class, stat growths and all that. Class system has great potential too if you like to grind for it, but I've seen others say that sticking to just one class for all your characters for the rest of the game will still suffice, but I personally made full use of the class change system since I like making overpowered characters.
Overall, it's a pretty nice game which could've used a lot more polishing here and there, but given this game's already a few years old, I doubt they'll make significant updates to the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027928203', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1154, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1565578253}
review:
It's a fun game, recommended if you like dungeon crawling and turn based rpg games.
A few tips to enjoy it more: Make a lot of characters as early as possible, because they can die often and they also take a lot of time to heal back to normal once they die.
Ambush a lot and early to get powerful armor and weapons that you cannot buy.
Seek the special monsters (lineage types) because they give special abilities that help a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053713663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 8422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8422, 'last_played': 1556561309}
review:
Stranger of Sword City is the first game in a specific genre that is unlike any other I have played before. Hardcore dungeon crawler, something I had no idea of before I first opened this game and dived in. After finally completing this adventure in it's entirety I can say so many things about it, both good and bad. 

Ultimately I think that this game lives to what it promises, and to what it wants to deliver as a game. It wants you to suffer, it wants you to feel proud when you prevail, and it wants to keep you on the edge of your seat wondering if you'll make it through the fight alive. Even if you do make it, who did you have to sacrifice along the way? Will you and all your friends make it home? What twist will the story and the game throw at you next?

Hardcore in every sense, unfriendly and missing the hand holding that many players would expect, you're completely on your own as you learn to navigate the treacherous land of Escario. While I can appreciate this, and know it's exactly the type of niche that this genre of game hits and expects you to adapt to, this game's difficulty for my taste is a bit of a skew from what i'd prefer in a game. The difficulty isn't in learning a pattern, or figuring out how to do what in the fight ahead of you. Well, that's not completely true but it's not completely wrong. 

Even if you play your best and excellently navigate the battle, much of the flow lies purely in numbers. Sometimes I fought a boss and completely stomped it within a few turns, the second time I fought that boss he destroyed half of my party in one turn. This game has such turbulent RNG that even the 99% chance to hit misses from Xcom would laugh at how silly it is. This type of pure chaos can be extremely funny, or extremely insufferable. Whatever you feel of it, it is the name of the game. Your only other ally than luck is well, influencing that luck, and by that I mean grinding your butt off and boosting your stats until you come back and own it. Or try to own it, before the dragon god attacks 27 times and does somewhere in the 10k+ range of damage to your team. Then the only thing you'll be owning is that reload button as you load up attempt number 7.

Gameplay is extremely hit or miss, and even as I say that I myself am highly conflicted on my total thoughts. I think personally I would love this game a lot more if it didn't have the extremely high difficulty (aka randomness and expectation that you know what you've gotten into so deal with it) and was a simpler, easier RPG that didn't require hours and hours of grinding loot and levels to overcome. That being said though, it is a part of the game that I grew with, and while I can't say I love the stuff i'm scoffing at, it would undeniably not be the same game without it. So... yeah. 

Outside of the gameplay I love this game. I love the theme, the music, the characters, all of it. The story starts out like any japanese rpg, fun and fluffy and inspiring. But this game is not a happy go lucky tale. It is dark, and as you proceed through your typical rpg adventure you learn the world around you isn't as simple a life as it seems. There are many moments of wonder, of sadness, of all sorts of feelings. Times I laughed or grinned and times I felt genuinely affected in a negative way by what I had experienced. Sometimes the adventure was weird or the connecting of the dots was strange, but for the most part, it's a roller coaster of a story that will take you on a roller coaster of emotions. 

Whether or not you choose to take up the mantle of the chosen one yourself, I have poured my heart into this blood crystal gem of a game, and as I lay it gently on the wall of conquests I've finished, I float off like a butterfly to wherever gaming takes me next. 

Farewell Sword City, I won't forget you anytime soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998775097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 6292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6292, 'last_played': 1555485477}
review:
Strangers of Sword City is a LONG JRPG Dungeon Crawler Wizardry / Might & Magic type of game.  While not AS hardcore as these titles, it is hardcore enough.  It has a decent good storyline and solid game play mechantics.  Be warned though at least 30-50 hours of this game you'll be grinding in the same spot(s) for awhile.

Perhaps the most hardcore part about this game is: death.  Death is unforgiveable, like Dark Souls.  Aside from the main character, if a character gets killed they lose a life point.  Should they lose all their life points, that character "vanishes" as so the lore states, which makes sense.

You have the option to revive them which takes time - time passes based on battles difficutly.  This alone takes a good 20-25 battles.  But then if you want to recover their life point, you have to hoptilzied them.  This can take an additional 30-50 battles!  While there are limited items that can recover them instantly, it's rare to get them.  You can also just pay gold, but that increases base on the characters level and gold doesn't drop as much.  So if you get whacked, sometimes it's best to start over.  That's what I did, at best lost 20 minutes of progress.  Death does NOT kid around!  It's safe to say, make backup characters as they level on the side as you do.  Leveling up doesn't take TOO long but it is a grind.

The battles and combat are tough, and sometimes the enemies RNG of what level you encounter can be brutafully high.  It's best to just run away at that point.  The game is pretty good about that since your first power is instant run away (other than boss battles).

Pros:  Old School Baldars Gate portraits are a nice touch for characters.
Dungeon Crawler feels with a good map system and fast travel to any location on a dungeon once you find it.
Long advetnure and challegning dungeons that keep you going.

Cons:  Death does not kid around
Can be a grind, be aware.
Special boss battles tend to show up too often in random battles atofore you have a chance to beat the regular enemies. I found this to annoying.  Lucikly, easy to run away from these special fights.
Not as many classes as I'd hope but enough to keep the game flow going.
Limited shop nearly everything you find will be on the field battle.

6/10 Overall enjoyed.

issues?
-your character choices and age aren't explained at first, so you can really mess yourself up not knowing it matters

author: {'steamid': '76561198047160036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 17603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10465, 'last_played': 1701797245}
review:
It was my first Dungeon Crawler and if I am asked if I feel remorse for buying it the answer is a clearly :NO. I love and hate this game at the same time. 

+ Story: I just love it. It starts mysertious and keeps this feeling/vibe up till the end.

+ Characters: I love them and it broke my heart a few times trough the story. But you can understand why they act most of the time while you play trough the story.

+ Music I love the music. It fits the battles, overworld and the base.

+ Graphic/Design Just gorgeous. The game is just beautiful. I love the style of the Characters, base and the world. The Monsters look really diffrent than every other game I have played before. Nothing is the same and the style reminded me of "Dark Tormentum" (great game try it)

+ Walking in the overworld: I am one oft those people that really enjoy walking and exploring the map with a feel of danger and I like some special things in each map. (teleportation wrong way suddenly poison gas, you cant use skills/spells great imrpvoement in difficulty)

+ Spells/Skills Classes. I love the diffrent type of spells/skills & of course the classes. You can battle in your own style and you have a front and backline. You can Attack, Defend, use items, Spells & skills and of course Divinity's

+ Divinitys: I Love this concept. Depending on your choices you will get diffrent Divinitys witch willl decide your fate in battle. And keeps it firrent everytime. Without the right one you will havea hard time (choose carefully but you will get most of them)

+ NG +: You can play with your same characters in a new game. Play the same game again but with a waaaay harder difficulty. Dont overestimate yourself. Even when you are highleveld you can be killed easy.

+ Ambushing: I love this feature, Some bosses can only be found with this feautre and the best way to collect equipment. You got 5 possible enemies to choose from. You dont like the first one? Just use pass. Is the last to dangerous? Leave them alone.(except for bosses! Be careful)

+ Storage: Great function that is located in the base. It is a combination with the shop wher you can sell/store equipment you dont need. It also shows you while takign the equipment out which character can use which.

+/- Character creation: Both positive and negative for me. You can choose your class and lookout (doesnt affect your stats) and hearts and one mastery. (Not get ambushed a lot, easy treasure opening for example) Sadly it also is a critic point. Skill points gain is random. Getting a 10 takes a looong time and you will need every point in the NG+ games. Not the best but also not the worst system.

+/- Difficulty: I mentioned above the lvl problem with enemies. That also fits the overall gameplay. This game isnt the easiest. Mistakes you can pay permanent death in the game. I enjoy a challenging game and you learn to play diffrent tactics.


Even tough I listed a lot of positive things there are still bad things that sometimes make me hate this game:

-Enemys: I listed above their unique being and great lookout. Their skills and beeing is the same. You will find out really early that even in a low lvl dungeon there hides an enemy that can  kill you with 1 hit and you dont stand a chance. Some enemies are just beyong hard and even grinding wont help you all the time. Play carefully and read everything and every hint in the battle and your memos it will/can save your life and give you tips how to beat them.

- Enemylvl: Connecting with the point above. Grinding helps you sometimes even more after a NG+, but a few bosses will show up with same highest level in your party. WATCH OUT. Also the level can jump from the same as you to about 10+ level higher  than your team.

-Class Change: I am happy we got this function. (can change a few times and get a few skilsl of each class you changed) The bad thing to keep if from beeing broken (it seems) is that you loose HALF of your lvl of the hero! Thats to much in my opinion and keeps me from changing.

- Items: Altough i love the diffent type of items I hate the way how to get a few.  Some items are essential to even pass a few stages of the game. (Epic hard boss battles the endgame for example!) And a few you can only buy 10 times each game (new games add 10 again) 10 revive items sounds a lot but there will be a lot of situations you will need them. Choose wisely! Read the discription and store them in the storage or you will waste them.

- Hearts/Lifepoints: Each character can have between 1-3 hearts. Everytime the character dies he looses a heart. If he loose all his hearts the character fanishes forever. No chance of getting them back. (except the main character revive him as often as you want) The first time it happend to me I was just: WHAT he is gone forever? So dont foreget to check your hearts and revive your partymembers/hearts early enough.

- Recovery/treat death. I mentioned the hearts above. The "Base" got the function instant recovery or normaly recovery the same is for the hearts. Instant recovery costs a lot of money, normal recovery takes a looong time. (a few days ingame time sometimes it feels like ages.


Overall a great game. I would buy it again and would hope for a DLC or SoSC2. Love it but it isnt the right  for everyone. I think a lot dislike it for the difficulty and the grinding. I like it. It helps me play careful and cautious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009317041', 'num_games_owned': 597, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 4259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1628, 'last_played': 1552524653}
review:
This game is a game made for fans of classic wizardries(5 and before) and and games like that. if you touched games like that and decided that's not your field of interest, well this is not for you.
with that out of the way, i can say that Stranger of Sword City is a very good game. it picks all the good stuff from classic wizardry and tweaks them just enough to make it a different game but that still feels like it, without changing it mechanically into something more jrpg-like 


i almost did not got this game, it just looked like a generic wizardry clone. and boy i was wrong. this is one of those rare games where you cannot say "oh it does things in a new way that games before it did not", is the whole package and how everything interconnects that is good.
if you go and read the classes descriptions, the spells, its mechanics and so... you won't be impressed. till you play the game.
a example: all of the fighting classes have special attacks but they neither became simple attack spells with weapons that use mp or (for most part) a universal replacement for normal attacks. each every single special attack has a tradeoff to it that never fully replaces the normal attack but at the same time they do cause a massive impact in combat... but if you just read a list of class skills, all you gonna see is "class A has 4 attack skills.... class B has 3.... how original"

this level of fine point balancing is everywhere in the game, and it tells how much love was poured into this and how well the devs knew the genre, there no way for me to not recommend it for anyone who's into the genre

author: {'steamid': '76561198009021982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 2076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1835, 'last_played': 1649609402}
review:
Interesting hard dungeon crawler game. You have a party of 6 (3 front/3 back) characters and 10 extra sitting at the base in case you need to change your party setup or when your characters lose a heart and need some time to recover. Dying in game is dangerous, characters can die at most 3 times depending on their age after that they are gone forever.

The game has an interesting way to farm items. You ambush groups of enemies and kill leaders before they flee with chests.

There are unique items that you can get. There is a system in a game when you can donate this item and this allows you to be able to find it again with better stats.

There is a class change system that you can use to gather some skills from different classes that will allow you to customize your characters better.

The game scares you with enemy levels. In your first dungeon when you are level 1 you can meet enemies of level 15 or higher. Sometimes you can still beat them. On level 13 with one class change you can beat level 35 enemies.

The amount of interesting and unusual features, plus difficulty of the game that does not only depends on stats but also on you knowing the enemy and how to apply your skills makes this game very interesting for people who appreciate dungeon crawlers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027882328', 'num_games_owned': 1730, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2742, 'last_played': 1637303443}
review:
Obnoxiously difficult. Bosses will frequently one-shot characters, either with an instant-kill attack (which can be blocked, past a certain point in the game or when certain classes get to a certain level) or by doing amounts of damage that are impossible to live through. It wouldn't be a huge problem if a single character could get one-shot by an attack, since you have 6. But it's very much possible for multiple characters to die turn 1. Not only that, but if characters die too many times (1-3 depending on their age) they permanently disappear.

Do not buy unless you are willing to read a guide, have a large amount of patience for frustration/repetition, and are fine with random game overs/character deaths that you have little/no control over. This isn't Dark Souls' kind of difficulty, where getting better makes the game easier. This is beating your head against a wall until the molecules in the wall line up perfectly so that your head goes through it. And then you die, because your head is inside a wall.

If you want a dungeon-crawler RPG that respects your time, I'd recommend Wizardry 8, Shining in the Darkness, Paper Sorcerer, Legend of Grimrock, or Might & Magic X.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992998161', 'num_games_owned': 1369, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 5654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5654, 'last_played': 1503419981}
review:
A very accessible blobber.
Easy to get into, nice menus that dont make you bend over backwards for repetitious shit like old blobbers. Automapping and abilities move from map.
Has great music. Two art styles that are "amazing" and "anime". Definitely go with amazing.

Its dungeons are very simplistic. You dont get claustrophobic dungeons and definitely never get lost.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129495050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1543032098}
review:
Normally I'd never write a bad review simply because a game doesn't start up on my computer, but a LOT of people have not only got the same exact issue, but have also had it since Nov of 2017. I checked the discussions page and I only found one response that MIGHT be from a dev, but when their answer didn't help, all contact was broken. The fact that this game is on sale when it's still buggy to the point where it's unplayable, annoys me. 

Bottom line: If you buy it and you get a white screen that says Not Responding, refund the game. You will not find a solution to the problem. The game also apparently crashes at other times as well...so often, the discussions page has a whole section on it. 

Not good if the developers aren't talking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013695344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1311, 'last_played': 1547641212}
review:
Un des meilleurs Dungeon Crawler auquel j'ai jouÃ©, l'univers et l'histoire reste plaisant Ã  suivre (mÃªme si on reste l'Ã©lu d'une certaine maniÃ¨re..) la DA du jeu type Dark Fantasy est tout simplement superbe et notamment les artworks des personnages (Type A) et les boss. 

Le jeu peut Ãªtre dÃ©courageant parfois il est vrai, lorsqu'un de tes meilleurs guerriers stuffÃ© aux petits oignons se fait one-shot par un coup critique funeste ou par un mob que tu as clairement sous-estimÃ© et il ne faut pas Ãªtre non plus allergique au grinding c'est certain. Mais c'est simplement car la difficultÃ© est au rendez-vous, une difficultÃ© qu'on ne trouve plus de nos jours dans les JRPG modernes, il faut apprendre Ã  constituer un groupe solide, Ã  prÃ©voir une Ã©quipe en backup, Ã  anticiper les changements de classes et Ã  quel niveau le faire...

Un aspect du jeu intÃ©ressant est le systÃ¨me de loot basÃ© sur des zones Ã  embuscade de mobs avec difficultÃ© accrue, c'est fun et le jeu sait punir une trop grande cupiditÃ© de votre part.

Soyez prÃ©venu : La mort d'un personnage se paye au prix cher. Si le challenge ne vous fait pas peur et qu'au contraire elle vous stimule alors ce jeu est fait pour vous.

Good luck Stranger ! Que la RNG soit avec vous.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968994186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1616081879}
review:
Game type: Dungeon Crawler

Player focus:  Single player; narrative driven player vs. environment game play.

Description: A first person perspective â€œdungeon crawlâ€ game the game holds the same gameplay as games such as Legend Of Grimrock or Might & Magic 10: Legacy. Developed by Experience Inc. & published by Nippon Ichi Software America the game does not offer any DLC for sale. With an average length of 50 to 60 hours (based on reports found via Google) the game appears (from the review period of 6 hours of play time) to offer little in the way of replayability as all classes are available from the start. Once the story is played through thereâ€™s little incentive to go through, once again, to try different builds or story lines.

Game Mechanics: Game play takes place in a corridor â€œdungeonâ€ (which includes outside areas). The map is divided into equal size squares with time & movement being based on movement from square to square. It fits the standard style of a dungeon crawl game. Movement can be done via wasd+qe or using the mouse to activate contextual direction prompts on screen. Combat takes place via turn based commands where the player first inputs their options & then watches as they play out & awaits the computerâ€™s opposing commands. The cycle continues until one side kills all of the opposing side.
With no physics to speak of the game engine is light weight & does not have long loading times in response. There are no 3D graphics with player character & enemy units being display via high quality portraits. Map graphics use what appears to be some form of perspective projection with textures stretching & blurring based on the cameraâ€™s location.
Difficulty wise the game appears decently difficult but mostly due to a lack of resources in the early game. With one character dying early on I was not able to revive said character due to the rather large sum of currency the game asks for revivingâ€¦ leading to slower game play progression & an underpowered party.
Controls are referenced in controller lingo & while keyboard & mouse controls do work the game lacks polish in this regard with on screen prompts always being referenced in a corresponding controller button.

Story: While not deeply into the story at only 6 hours of playtime the story so far has presented itself as a â€œhuman world normal person encounters established fantasy world thereby becoming the chosen oneâ€ story. Others speaking on the story have indicated there are some twists to the story but one does not expect these to be outside the normal set of tropes for such a setting.

Art Style/Graphics:The map graphics are quality textures that are displayed in varying qualities. If a texture is observed directly, such as the tiles one must cross while adventuring, quality is relatively pleasant  with a few set pieces helping populate an otherwise barren â€œdungeonâ€.
The user interface graphics are simple; being presented with edged text boxes & complementary coloured prompts & highlights they neither detract nor enhance gameplay.
Character portraits are the gameâ€™s strong point. These are quite often lovely to look at with eye catching highlights & deep colours. However, at least in the case of the player portraits, they can also detract from the game play as several of the provided portraits use bright, cheerful colour schemes which do not seem to fit with rest of the gameâ€™s set pieces at all.

Sound/Music: With most game interactions (selecting an option for instance) being indicated with a simple click the interface sounds are minimal. The music does not tend to stand out & does not really engage one to the story.
Many of the dialogs are voiced, however since the game originated as a Asian game all voices are in a Asian dialect as NISA did not see fit to include voice acting in the porting process.

Target/Suggested Audience: With the game play being a bit on the harder side but also more simplistic then similar games the target audience appears to be individuals who donâ€™t mind gameplay grind but want an accompanying story.

Pricing: Currently $21 Canadian on Steam & no DLC offered the game is overpriced compared to more engaging games of the same theme such as the fore mentioned Legend Of Grimrock which can be had for only $15 at the time of writing.

Summary of Pros: Lovely character & enemy portraits, ability to import oneâ€™s own portraits. Short load times.

Summary of Cons: Overpriced, game play thatâ€™s simplistic compared to competitors, textures that are blurry during world exploration, seemingly little motivation for replay. NISA driven port to English & PC is unpolished with keyboard/mouse support being tacked on & no English translation for audio.

Reviewed copy obtained via: Direct Steam purchase.

Recommendation Level: Not recommended; other products of similar design have better presentation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102655125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1539832658}
review:
Alot of people are buying it for the ability to add custom portraits into the game so you can have Captain Crunch as your Main Character or something as goofy as that.

Personally i find the game to be Boring and unimaginitive on many fronts but mainly the way the world looks and how simple and dull battle is.

Basically just a Test game made by newer developers that japan likes to do sometimes because people will still buy them. For me id give a hard pass even for low amount of cost they are charging.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082788781', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1539812160}
review:
Extremely unintuitive. The first hour of the game is just throwing you into menus and menus without you even knowing what the hell to do. I've been trying to be very cautious and aware of what the game tells me to do but the imbalanced combat, the completely weird levels of every character and the weird ass perspective are nothing for me. 

Get Etrian Odysee for DS. You'll have a version of this game that is actually good, actually even playable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991732326', 'num_games_owned': 499, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 8653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8567, 'last_played': 1619656107}
review:
The game starts with the news of plane crashing down, and you was in the plane, but instead of dying, you find yourself taken to another world, Escarion - a place, where you are not the only one transported, as lot of stuff from our world often end there, as there is lot of broken planes, trains and even ships around, in this place you character is called a "Stranger", because people from other world, are not only stranger in this place, but wield different powers here. But you soon get yourself in a trouble as misterious stranger lead you to a trap only to be saved by another Stranger, a young girl named Riu, which also came from our world, she saves you and take you to the Sword City - from this point on - begin your adventures as a "Stranger in Sword City" a Dungeon Crawler from Experience published by Nisa.

Now while you start with a single character at the beginning, you can (and should) create a party, the game offer the classic array of classes, but each one have some unique features - Knight (which have skills based in attacking enemies in rows and other to protect the party), Samurai (which focus in dual wielding, attacking enemies in lines and engaging in one to one duels) , Fighter (which can concentrate to unleash powerfull attacks), Ranger (focused in long range and tie down enemies), Ninja (with critical hit based skills and evasion based skills), Dancer (which have a variety of skills, which allow them thing like using two or more item at once, hitting enemies no matter their position), Cleric (Healing and Buff magic) and Wizard (Attack and buff spells).

The game features a "Life Point" system, each character will have a certain amount of "Life points" depending on their age (younger character get more while older less) and each time a character dies a point will be lost, if all points are lost them the character will be lost forever, thankfully, there is both items (but rare) which heal Life and you can recover them by resting on the StrangerÂ´s base with either time or gold (instantly). However, your main character, due story reasons, isnÂ´t affect by Life Point loss despite how many times they might die (but this is only for the MC the rest of the party work as normal).

Most of the game will be around finding and hunting the Lineage types of each map, unique monsters encounters that often require some condition to me meet, defeating them wield Blood Crystals, which could be given to three NPCs, each one unlocks special abilities, called Divinity and also set which ending you might see - Riu will lead to the Neutral ending, Marilith to the Good ending and Alma to the Bad ending. By doing this hunts you unlock more of the story and newer maps to go.

The Divinity is one of the game most curious features, as you characters attack enemies they will gain Morale, and his could be spend using the Divinity, each one have different effects, such as giving your whole party ability to attack first, recover HP each turn, protect from certain spells and other types of buffs - knowing how to use them will be often very crucial during both Lineage types and Boss battles, which might often require a careful timing.

The ambush system is another of interesting features of the game, where instead of grind random encounters around the map, your major source of XP and gear will come from the from the "Ambush Points" scattered in each map, in this places, by spending a bit of Morale, you can set, as much the name suggest, an ambush, where you might find different monster groups, each one carrying a potential treasure, where you can choose to attack them or let them pass (in case their treasure isnÂ´t good or they are to powerful) and see if you can spot another one. Also majority of the Lineage types you face will be in ambush points.

This system mean you have much wider control when you grind, since you can have much better idea of what might get from the encounter and therefore, grind almost exactly what you need. Like if you need a new Katana, you might just go around a map where in ambush points you might find monster parties carrying Katana chests and ambush them.

There is also a system for multiclass your characters, where at any point you can chance your class to another one (but at half your current class level, so if you are 20 Level Knight and change to Samurai, you will be at level 10), but you allow to carry around some skills for the previous class, with the Token skills, at certain levels, each class gain certain Token Skill points, each one let you choose a skill from the previous class to keep around (and you can change them at anytime). Using this system is often crucial at late game, where you might need a combination of different class skills to survive.

Another fun feature, is that you can choose the art style of the game, as the game features to main artists, one with a more high fantasy and another more dark fantasy in style. You can also set up your own custom portraits too. Note: the screenshots used in the review are from the more dark fantasy themed art.

The game it is very good, the pace feels right, thanks to both the grid based maps never felling to huge or small and even the grind isnÂ´t much a issue, as you have much better control of what you might get, while Lineage battles offer a interesting challenge. It is important to add, the PC version is so called "White Palace"(ç™½ã®ç‹å®®) version, because there is different versions of the game, the vita is the "Black Palace"(é»’ã®å®®æ®¿) the major different between them is some Lineage bosses and if the one of the end dungeons is either the Black Palace of the White Palace.  After the main story, which isnÂ´t much very long by itself, but leveling up and hunting gear might take its time, there is some post game content - the first based around the so called White/Black Palace map, the second is about visiting four new dungeons with some new bosses, which are extra hard. By last, there is a NG plus system too.

Downsides? I do admit, that while there might be some, most of them where rather minimal, like some bosses can be really hard without good divinity skills, like ones which cast charm, which require you to have a certain divinity skill in hand and ready to cast or risk losing control of the situation, but, again this rather minimal, as the game kind warn you to have this skill ready by time bosses start to use it. However, depending of which ending you are looking that might mean straying away a bit or twice (spoilers: there is a single boss, which cast charm twice, so you might need a upgrade version of the skill which protect you two times from charm). Also a few bosses have skills which can instantly kill a character if you arenÂ´t ready.

One final point, the game music is gorgeous, specially, the lineage music.

author: {'steamid': '76561198219712557', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1533410596}

author: {'steamid': '76561197986104200', 'num_games_owned': 475, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1483, 'last_played': 1535352196}
review:
If you think you'll like the game you probably will.  Great art, a good amount of depth and variation available, great atmosphere. 

If they were to make a second that has character animations and slightly more detail and effects, it would get AAA sales and respect.   I thought long before buying it and read many reviews and criticisms, but I'm really glad I picked it up.  I'll be sinking MANY hours in this over time and it is well seated within my game playlist rotation.

I would recommend reading the forum thread regarding things people wish they knew when they started, it will equip you with what you need to know to be able to enjoy the tango with this games ever-present threat and ability to kill you if you disrespect the real game at hand between taking risks for enticing rewards and gear while meanwhile building a roster of characters that will earn you money while your main party is out braving the "dungeons" for hijacked pillaging and quest or exploration rewards.

I look forward to see how the story develops as there is a long way for me yet to go, while I plot and build my character's builds and gear to be able to survive what I find around that next new area or surprise encounter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198236937684', 'num_games_owned': 84, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1582807509}
review:
For me Stranger of Sword City is the worst Dungeon Crawler so far.

Difficulty change in the middle of a map why? XP rate is as low as it can be. My characters are lvl 10 and thats it after 7.5 hours. Don't expect any of the main story before you grind your ass off. Shop items like phoenix feathers are limited this is complete bullshit. Characters have EXTRA LIVES?! and to refill them you have to grind your ass off AGAIN because you have no money?! If you don't do it there are gone for good after 1-3 deaths. Yeah great shit and so much fun you can create new characters woohooo this is just annoying.

It's not a must play game
it's not fun
it's just one of the worst dungeon crawler

author: {'steamid': '76561197979991287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2033, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2033, 'last_played': 1482251163}
review:
This was very close to a non-recommended title for me, but the people who don't mind the 1 nagging con, will absolutely love this game.

It's difficult for me to recommend this game, despite all of the excellent things it has going for it.

*Gameplay is fun
*The art & music are most pleasing
*The character interactions feel a lot better than in your typical JRPG (technically Dungeon Crawler, in this case)
*Overall, the feel of the game is incredible

The one massive nagging thing, as with every Nis title in existence, is the endless, pointless, in relatively profitless grinding. Grinding to the point where the good feeling is sucked from the game. Any notions of a story are lost in the sea of endless battles. And every time you grind hard, get ahead, and feel like you've made enough improvement to move forward unhindered; the very next dungeon vaults you into peasantry once again. Then, when you believe you've actually made a significant dent, you reach the "next tier" where your characters are seasoned veterans compared to a few hours ago, but they're no better than beginning adventurers when you travel to your next destination.

Every
Nis
Game
Does
This.

If you don't mind the endless grind, I practically implore you to check out this real gem of an artistic creation. If you do, avoid it like the plague.

review:
NÃ£o se deixe enganar pela bela arte do jogo. Stranger of Sword City Ã© um jogo bonito, com mecÃ¢nicas e interfaces simples, mas que escondem uma dificuldade de deixar qualquer "cabra macho" parecer um "pintinho".

O jogo Ã© um Dungeon Crawler de respeito, que exige do jogador a total compreensÃ£o dos elementos da batalha para "tentar" nÃ£o morrer. Sim, esse jogo exige que vocÃª tenha o devido respeito para com os inimigos, pois foge do padrÃ£o de dificuldade que estamos habituados.

A premissa do jogo, bastante dolorosa, exige sacrifÃ­cios em momentos bem delicados, o que requer uma dosa bem cavalar de adrenalina para seguir em frente. Entretanto, a morte nÃ£o significa essencialmente o fim, mas um olhar mais contundente da dificuldade que ele entrega ao jogador: morreu, erga um novo exÃ©rcito e siga em frente.

A histÃ³ria, um tanto quanto clichÃª, esconde seus momentos dramÃ¡ticos, aliada Ã  dificuldade do jogo que EXIGE MUITA PACIÃŠNCIA DO JOGADOR. O sistema de aquisiÃ§Ã£o de armas (grind) Ã© muito original e desafiante: inimigos mais fortes sÃ£o ossos duros de matar, mas escondem recompensas valiosas. A mÃºsica Ã© instigante e oferece trilha sonora bem consistentes.

Esse jogo oferece uma dificuldade bem justa, mas altamente desafiante; diferente de  Darkest Dungeons, que Ã© injusta, depende da sorte e oferece um prisma bem sÃ¡dico aos jogadores.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048066158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1530135442}
review:
The concept is fun, and the story was ok for the short depth that I traversed. In the end I just couldn't stand this games brand of grind. It is mindnumbingly dull, I think its hook is you grind for chests so you get that small thrill of possibility over and over again, of course most chests are filled with garbage...

For me the killer was progress effeciency/fairness. An example, in the starter dungeon, i ground and ground and got my party up to level 4-6 (less than 5 average). Most fights are against level 11 hydra team, and go auto - auto - auto win. Then every now and again I would hit level 22's, (whom you can easily flee from) and lets say you want to go for it! They can one-shot your team members putting them out for 8 in-game days, that is 2-4hours of IRL grinding.  Or, and this is the kicker, if you win!, i would get 1-3% xp gain. That is a horrible payout for pushing your team. 

To reiterate the game has charm but relies on random loot drop thrill too much to overcome the repetition for me, as a working adult I don't have the time to toss off on a game of this much grind to play ratio. If you do though, and the game looks charming to you ignore my don't recommend that is toward people who have more limited time resources.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009690561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1300, 'last_played': 1553599826}
review:
A difficult-tish JRPG similar to the Wizardry series. Very polished and pleasing to look at. Tends to be a bit grindy at the beginning so stay away if thats not your thing.

 Alot of people complain about the game being too hard, but I've always found ways to get around the challenges. Interesting story and characters with multiple endings.

Very much worth it if your a fan of old school RPGs.

Tip - Don't be afraid to run, lol

author: {'steamid': '76561197966556534', 'num_games_owned': 504, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 8179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4909, 'last_played': 1561826534}
review:
I don't think I've got very far in the game yet so please ignore my played time, the game has been left on overnight several times. However if you like party-based square-grid tile dungeon crawlers with turn-based combat, like any modern Wizardry game or Etrian Odyssy, this game is up your alley. It includes quality-of-life features like auto-move on the field and fast actions/memorized actions in battle. The story is probably good, I am not the right person to talk about it really because I more care about the dungeon crawling. Anyway, you're the chosen one stranded in a mysterious land who's going to kill all the boss monsters and ???maybe save the world??? it's pretty vague but everyone seems sure something good will happen. You can also choose to ally yourself with one of three different ladies who all want the crystals you get from defeating the boss monsters. You get different powers from them depending on who you decide to give your crystals to. Fairly standard and straightforward stuff, but suffers from pretty mediocre translation.

The dungeon crawling so far is pretty good, but pretty straightforward. No puzzles so far, but there are "unlockable" shortcuts and warp stones. There are rare random battles just walking around, as well as encounters you can see on the field. Battles take place in a separate screen, and each side basically goes simultaneously. You can select actions in any order, but then both sides actions are performed together in order based on stats. Again, pretty standard stuff.

So if everything is pretty standard, why recommend it and why bother buying it? Because it's not well represented on the PC in the west at all, and I do the majority of my gaming on the PC. I like the way this old genre has been reimagined and updated for modern sensibilities and then reimported back to us. This game, while not perfect, isn't objectionable or adult and takes the right lessons from the games its inspired by. The production values are indie-game level and the art available to choose from for characters is of questionable/variable quality. The game itself has been perfectly solid, no crashes or game-stopping bugs. The controls are nice and smooth and worked without rebinding on my 360 controller, although it looks like everything is configurable through an options menu. The game can also be played with keyboard and mouse which works for everything and is sufficient, but one of the benefits of this modern incarnation of the genre is not needing the keyboard and mouse.

The takeaway here is if you like dungeon crawlers like Etrian Odyssey or the modern console Wizardry games, then this is that game on PC. You won't be blown away, but you'll be right at home.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003369814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2175, 'last_played': 1523459675}
review:
Beautiful game with an interesting feel which i just cannot get into.. i tried.

all too often you are cruising through crap mindlessly because the indigenous life is such trash that you mow it down just trying to fill out your mapo when oops.. the encounter that is normally barely noticeable? well this is the exact same monsters just all 10 levels higher for so reason and it looked exactly like the last 17 you mowed through. well damn i guess i better just be more mindful and check everytime anyways.. enter mausoleum of forests where there is an area where the monsters levels are not revealed so now you cannot check.. educated quess? looks just like the last 9 groups i mowed through holding the A button down. nope guess not, one turn in and three characters are dead..

so i suppose the new paradigm is flee from all unknown encounters and pray it works?

I realize they want your characters to die and have to be circulated in and out, but i guess i just feel too invested in the builds i was going to do and going through ambushes/back to town/ ambushes/ etc grinding out gear. it aggravated me when in a single turn someone dies.. there's nothing i can do about it. If these people are disposable trash they should make them feel that way, not like super strong epic heroes of the story. Hell, go disgaea and reward people after bringing enough corpses back for recovery.

well i'm sure some folks enjoy this kind of thing, I wanted a dungeon crawler I could mow through without " alt-f4 and start again from last save " being done more often then getting through a spot like this.

in summation i suppose the problem is the random level spike they throw in occasionally just to screw you over. add to this the fact that sometimes it is completely stealth because they do that whole " hide the monsters name and level " thing at the beginning of encounters.
