author: {'steamid': '76561198011897794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1521312023}
review:
Uh Oh. 

Before leaving a review, I usually browse through the other reviews and see the percentage of people that share my opinion. In this case, I am one of the very small number of people not recommending this game for the actual gameplay, and not problems getting it to run properly. So here's the with my experience on this one so far:

Problem one. The grinding. 
-Usually I love a good dungeon crawling RPG with lots of grinding and powering up your party. This is one of the top reasons I bought this game. However the combat in this game is crazy. The battles activate randomly as you walk around on the map, and they are too infrequent. I'm 6 hours into the game now, and about 4 of those have been walking in circles to get a battle going. To make things worse, the battles are insanely easy. 90% of the fights, my party doesn't even take a point of damage. I just keep hitting the fastest autobattle button to finish the fights in less than 10 seconds. Wait, if the game is so easy, why don't I just continue to a new area with harder monsters? Well, that takes us to...

Problem two. The balance. 
-Like I said before, my party is so strong I rarely take a hit. Then the next random battle spawns an enemy which is actually pretty challenging. All my characters have ~100hp each, and then I get a guy who hits for 130+ damage in one swing. Continue forward to...

Problem three. The penalty for dying in combat. 
-Ok now I have to check my character in for recovery. It takes "One day" of game time for him to recover. This means I now have to pop in another party member and now go grind with someone new. This already kinda sucks, but it still manages to get worse. Each character has "Life Points" which is represented by 1-3 hearts. When a character dies, they lose a heart. If they die with no hearts left, they vanish forever. At least you can restore hearts....but to do so you have to check your character in for another "Seven days" of game time to get a heart back. Yes. More grinding secondary characters to add to your already painful grind time. And no, there is no way to just go to an inn and pass the seven days. Time only advances while you're out grinding in the dungeon. 

Ok so like I mentioned, I'm only 6 hours in so far. Maybe it's just the first 6 hours that are like this, and I'll soon start unlocking features which turn this into my fave game of all time. Beyond everything that I previously explained, I'm still managing to enjoy it a  bit and have no interest in quitting yet. If that's the case, I'd change my review and just give a warning that the beginning of the game is a bit of a pain. 

Or if you're one of the lovers of this game and feel like I'm just overlooking something and this review is wrong. Let me know in the comments. Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006222498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 2287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2081, 'last_played': 1527982832}
review:
One of those old-school dungeon crawlers that makes you forget you played it for 5 hours straight. I picked it up when it came out, but barely scratched the surface of it. I then started playing Might and Magic 3 recently. I got hooked on it again. I then saw this title in my library and thought I should give it another shot. Am I glad that I did.

Lots of fighting, lots of grinding, lots of loot (and with a unique yet interesting system to get it), and a bit of running. It's right in the vein of older series of dungeon crawlers like Wizardy, and Might and Magic. It's definitely not like newer rpgs, where basically every encounter is winnable. 

Character creation has some interesting things to it. Mostly with setting the age of the character. Young characters have the most life points with 3 (he/she loses 1 point each time they fall in battle), but very little bonus points to distribute when created. On the other hand, the old characters have the most attribute points at creation, yet only have 1 life point. So if they die, they're dead for good.

You'll be swapping party members on a regular basis, as characters get injured and need to rest. The good thing is, your reserve characters still gain some xp while not in your party, so they don't lag too far behind. They also generate a bit of income as well. Just make sure to check their equipment!

All in all, if you like grindy, loot-filled, hard-mode rpgs, then pick this one up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198343746367', 'num_games_owned': 2177, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 3318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3318, 'last_played': 1513241031}
review:
on the surface, stranger of sword city looks like most typical dungeon crawlers, and perhaps in many ways, it is. for those of you who are expecting something in the vein of 'legend of grimrock', you might be a bit disappointed. but if you are expecting something closer to the vein of 'wizardry', then you're in luck.

stranger of sword city has a heavy focus on combat, and as such, creating characters that would serve your party well, and planning skills for each character to use in combat. in terms of exploration however, there's only so many dungeons, and not too many 'hidden' areas that arent obvious to the player.

playing through the game however, you will be entertained by brilliantly done visuals (which you can also customize if you so wish), and interesting looking places (although limited). the soundtrack can get a bit repetitive, but it's not all bad however.

what keeps a player going, and playing or replaying the game, would be mostly about experimentation on the different (albeit a bit limited) classes, and their skills. the drawback however, being that some classes are just a bit too powerful, and would almost certainly be cycled into most characters' class changes.

the story isnt too bad either. it starts off sounding pretty corny, but it is fairly interesting, and it comes with multiple endings, which should give enough initiative for some players to replay it a few times.

all in all, it's a game that might take a while for you to really sink your teeth into, experimenting with classes and skills, and probably screwing up your builds a few times before getting it right. but once you get going, it can get pretty fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039621871', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1501649792}
review:
Great game.


Classical 90s style RPG.
Utilizes the 3D dungeon crawl structures of that era. 
Good story. 

Challenge. Choices. No politics. 

Weak in equipment choices, but this is counter-balanced by it not being primary to the gaming.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031190155', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 7494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7352, 'last_played': 1516069407}
review:
Okay, let's try and keep this short

The main problem here is the lack of any sort of end game. Classes get pretty lack luster skills, and because there is no stamina system, they have to be gimped in some way to avoid being OP, but, OP is fun, hitting 6 times after concentrating for one round at 1/2 accuracy isn't.

At first you see that class change system and think "oh can't wait to build some cool min/max type stuff", but you literally need maybe 5/6 skills that every character needs, and they will suit whatever role perfectly, just throw them back into their original class once you have them. With the lack of high level, fun skills leveling up because pointless except to keep up with random encounters, since you can brutally alter hit/dodge points through triple casting.

So in the end you have high level, everything classed characters whom don't really feel all that different from when you maxed your first class. The progress drops sharply once you picked up a few abilities, and every boss comes down to "spam avoid till 99, spam damage" with some tactical choice in between.

So if it's cheap, i could say get it and beat it once, but it's not really a memorable experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147337725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1628688831}
review:
Warning! This game is NOT for kids!

Pros:
-A trully Dungeon Crawler game.
-Beautiful Dark Fantasy Artwork / and Moe Anime type artwork (Depend on your taste)
-Beautiful Soundtrack.
-Characters Crearion.
-Reply Value.
-Multiple Endings.
-Waifus/Heroines.
-Class combinations

Neutral (Depend on individual taste):
-Hard game. Dark Souls level of Hard.
-No hand holding. 
-Random Encounters.
-Perma-Death.
-Great game mechanics.
-The Story. It's okay in my book.

Cons:
-Some details mechanic of the game aren't clearly told. 
-Random/Dice based stats alocation.
-The game have two types/versions that favored different endings.
-Grind. A lot of them. 

Stranger of Sword City is a hardcore dungeon crawler game. It follows its root very clearly and if you're looking for a Dungeon Crawler game that don't hold your hand you're going to enjoy this game. Its art style and music are well made (even the B type artwork) and the gameplay is smooth. The multiple endings and class combinations made the game worth replaying once you're finished. So if you love hard, old style dark fantasy Dungeon Crawler with beautiful art, music, okay story and gameplay then you'll enjoy this game. 
If you're a fan of anime/manga, then there's a button to change all the characters to an anime version in the option (Type B art). If you don't then just ignore it. 

Overall, I recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007434328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2014, 'last_played': 1518820728}
review: Was working before I installed the Windows 10 fall creator update on 19 November 2017.  Now, the window comes up when I run the game, but no animations occur (the screen remains black).  I hope a fix emerges soon.  Also, Steam will not refund the game despite the fact that they are actively advertising (and pushing to the top of their algorithms) a game that is likely to stop working a day or two into playing (which is convieniently more than their 2 hour limit).

author: {'steamid': '76561198038866015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1511584606}
review:
Do NOT buy this game, unless you have win 7/pre-creator's update installed to win 10, as there is NO support for this game as it's 100% unplayable due to a black screen...I will update my review when the problem is solved, so for now, let this serve as a warning that the game is non-functional and you would have wasted your money otherwise!

[h1]UPDATE: The devs made an appearance in the forums and are currently addressing this issue, so I'll have a [i][u]proper review[/u][/i] as soon as it's fixed and I can play the game! Nov 22 2017, three crashes later and I'm still unable to play this...Rolled a 14 on a 30 yr old player I will not play this again, and will wait until Monday for a proper patch as I'm 50 minutes into my refund period![/h1]

[h1]UPDATE 2: I refunded the game shortly after as I got it to start but it still constantly crashed, though to be fair, people with post win 10 fall update was able to get it working, so it is not out of the realm of possibility that I will eventually get this game again with a deep discount...So until then...[/h1]

review: Difficult Dungeon Crawler with a lot of flexibility when it comes to character/party building, i was pleasant to find the story actually REALLY interesting, really dark and mysterious that kept me wondering what's gonna happen next at all times. definetly worth it for people who like challenging RPGs and/or people who enjoy stories that make you piece everything together (specially since the base price of the game went from $40 to $20).

author: {'steamid': '76561198273254344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1510897900}
review:
I'm a huge fan of many similar games, such as the Etrian Odessey series, Wizardry series, and many more.  

This one just feels bad, though.

Pros:
-Graphics
-Fast combat option

Cons:
-Unimaginative classes and abilities
-Limited viable group compostitions
-Long, boring cutscenes
-JRPG cliche after cliche

It's just not fun, despite the (mostly) great art.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041381640', 'num_games_owned': 925, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1341, 'last_played': 1541554974}
review:
This is one of the better games I've played this year.  I grew up on JRPGs from the SNES and PSX era, but in the last few years have been looking for a game like this.  Something like Wizardry.  I love the concept of creating a party where I decide classes and skills, and this allows an immense level of customisation there.  The only problem I have with the game is it can be very grindy, but with music as good as it has, and a battle system this well tuned, I can forgive it.

It's also worth noting that in 22 hours I've not had a single bug, glitch, or other example of poor coding.  

IF you like JRPGs give this a whirl.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020777628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1511430416}
review:
I bought SoSC for PC on 23.10.2017 and installed it just after I installed the Update of Windows 10 Creator Pack Fall on my Notebook and my Desktop PC. Game did not even start on both systems. I only got a black window screen without any sound or activity. I tried all suggested old solutions (1.5 years old)  in the forums, but nothing helped.
Last input of developer in the forum is about 1.5 years ago, no reaction on new threads so far.  I contacted the support on 24.10.2017 and did not received any answer on my request for help with this issue by email until now.
According to the forums other players have similiar issues, probably since Windows 10 Creator Pack Fall Update, maybe this is the source of the problem for this game.
So far I cannot recommend to buy this game, as there is no support for the PC version in sight and no fix appeared since release to solve those issues reported in the forums.
I had to request a refund ,unfortunately.

Update 23.11.2017: Finally, the developers of the game have reacted and released beta fix for the game, which makes it playable for Window 10 users with Fall Upgrade 2017. Great, the game is a quite nice tactical and complex Dungeon Crawler. I like it so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198254953058', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1579420331}

author: {'steamid': '76561197973580399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 6764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6733, 'last_played': 1573338480}
review:
Among the earliest PC RPGs were the dungeon crawlers - the Might & Magics, Dungeon Masters, and the Wizardries.  In the US, dungeon crawlers fell out of fashion around the time that modems and video cards became a thing, and despite the odd throwback like Legend of Grimrock, our RPG development took a different track.  In contrast, Japan fell in love with the Wizardry style of dungeon crawler (even getting some actual Wizardry games we didn't), and have been putting them out for years.  Recently, those Japanese dungeon crawlers have been getting localized for our audiences, largely on portables - your Etrian Odyssies, Dark Spires, etc.  NIS has taken a number of their Vita dungeon crawlers and brought 'em to PC.  Sword City is one such example.

It's pretty good!  You've got some of the standard Wizardry-like tropes - generic characters you create, class changing to build more powerful teams, potential for permadeath (excluding your hero), guess-the-trap style loot chests, unmapped dungeons with environmental hazards and hidden doors, that sort of thing.  You've also got Etrian Odyssey style hunts for "Lineage types", minibosses that can tear you up much like a good FOE would.  There's even a Shin Megami Tensei style Law/Neutral/Chaos split, albeit with less extreme behavior on both sides.  

Combine all that with a nice system where you acquire gear by ambushing enemy groups at designated spots and some nicely challenging boss fights, and you could certainly do far worse if you want a relatively story light, dungeon-crawling, monster-bashing way to spend some time.

One caveat; there's a remastered version of Sword City available on Vita, with some extra classes, some balance tweaks, etc.  It may or may not be coming to PC, so if you want the remaster then you'll either want to grab that version or take a wait-and-see approach here.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995962876', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 5903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5903, 'last_played': 1509053306}
review:
Actually fun and nicely done dungeon crawler that however suffers from somewhat limited content. Everything is in place, working correctly but game screams "I need more dungeons/classes/weapon types/enemies/bosses to show you what Im capable of!". Aside from that, it have few interesting mechanics (divinity skills and morale, ambushes mechanics for getting new equipments, hunting for "lineage types" aka minibosses for unlocking story progress and more skills) and nice 30-60+ hours content to play, if you dont mind bonus and post-game stuff (that can easily pump gameplay time up to 100+ hours). Kinda grindy if you actually do want to clear this optional stuff.

I suggest to grab it on sale (easier now since price got permanently lowered from 36 to 20 EUR) but if you like turn-based dungeon crawlers and especially if you played and enjoyed Class of Heroes (VERY similar game), you will enjoy this game as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067497741', 'num_games_owned': 414, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 2432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2335, 'last_played': 1507440920}
review: A boring dungeon crawler which takes forever to actually do anything in it. At first it was a fun game but after a while it started to drag and make grinding tedious and boring. Also the game utilizes randomnes as its main point, it some cases it can be good, but instead givng randomness as an element, the game is fully based on it, which makes you feel like in an unfair version of Dark Souls, where everythng is made to kill you wihtou mercy, but here you actually cant get better. Ive played many japanese dungeon crawlers and all where made on a similar formula to Etrian Odyssey, where your choices in party build and characters skill builds would either reward you or punish you, In stranger of sword city it actually does not matter, cause the randomess kills any point in being prepared. Dont recommend this game, sadly it was supposed to be better than Demon Gaze, but its not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198281568815', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 15750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7451, 'last_played': 1516690919}
review:
Here is a personal review of Stranger of Sword City. (from someone who does not know the Anime)
Hopefully I can be of a little help for you to decide on playing this game.

=Long story short=
If you like dungeon-crawling, multi-classing, grinding, and/or farming, get it.
If you like spending hours and hours building your character up, get it.
If you are a Wizardry fan, get it. Period.

=Short story long=
This is what you get.

Portrait - very nice built in portraits, import custom portraits
Age - Age affects times of death (can always heal so no problem here) and bonus roll points for attribute. Younger have more life, older has more bonus points.
Race - Human, Elf, Dward, Migmy (something like a Gnome in D&D), Ney (a cat/fox-human hybrid)
Talents - Fortunate (bonus attribue points), Educated (better identify items), Invincible (no one shot death), Intuition (better identify treasure/traps), Wild Eye (better finding secret doors)
Attributes - Strength, Intellegence, Piety, Vitality, Agility, Luck
Class - Fighter, Knight, Samurai, Ranger, Ninja, Dancer, Cleric, Wizard (no class has attribue requirements)
Character voice - Chose from 36 different voice (some good, some too mechanical). Attack, Damage, and Death voice.
Name and Nickname - (if you cannot chose, just name them the same)
6 equipment slots - Main hand, Off hand, Head, Body, Underwear, Accessory

Think this will cover the basic game system.

Here are my 'personal' pros/cons:
=Pros= (in no order)
Artwork of portrait
Custom portraits, importing custom portraits is just an awesome +
Control is very easy, could use only keyboard or mouse throughout the game (can customize hot-keys)
Interesting story line
Automatic mapping, auto-run to point already explored (this is a great option!)
Class change system (upto 5 times for a total of 6 classes)
Many different equipments (including Unique one-of-a-kind items)
Ambushing (or rather item farming - set up amush at certain map locations to steal chests)

=Cons=
Artwork of portrait (some artwork are mobs lol)
Control - There are no hot-keys for combat options (example [A]ttack, [D]efend, S[K]ill, [S]pell). So you will have to mouse click or navigate with movement keys.
Story line - The English text is very repetitive, don't know about Japanese. The plot giver (NPC) repeates the same thing in different wording many times. (my example: Make sure to give your mom a hug. Hug your mom, okay?. Don't forget to hug your mom before you leave. Huging your mom is showing that you appreciate her.)
Many different equipment (but many becomes obsolete - just trash, the stat difference between some equipment are too great)
One-hit-death, the critical strike (many people will think this as a con just because the mobs have it. But remember, you do also. Besides, there are skills and talent and spells that can protect you from them so not a big deal later on)
Not enough spells nor diversity

=Conclusion=
A little clumsy overall, but that's the attractiveness that keeps me going.
It's fun when you find a Dirty underwear +10 and think about wearing it because you have a Leather Undie +2.
Very very enjoyable game and is highly recommended for it's genre.

PS: don't forget to hug your mom =)

author: {'steamid': '76561197972431515', 'num_games_owned': 976, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 650, 'last_played': 1491753183}
review:
I have a long history and love affair with dungeon crawlers, starting with Might and Magic 1. I really enjoyed Etrian Odyssey 1-3. I've dabbled in Wizardry (mostly 8) and several of its misbegotten clones on multiple consoles, including the Vita. I think this game is hot garbage.

Yes, the art is cool. Since that's the big draw, the first complaint I have about this game is that the character art is split between the nice art, and woefully derivative anime garbage. This ensures that unless you want to jump through hoops to import your own art, you will actually have a very small selection of stylistically consistent portraits that will suit your race and class choices.

Next, this is a game with boring, been there done that races and classes. If you've played one copy-cat wizardry clone, you've played them all. Nothing to see here folks. The big gimmick for character customization is... a somewhat convoluted multi-class system. Take another boring, ho-hum class and grind extra? OH BOY, CAN I??

I thought Dancer would be cool, but it's actually completely useless at low levels. I've got a level 8 character doing a whopping 3 damage EVERY OTHER TURN (he has to set up, otherwise he does just one damage) in large part because the gear you find is very subject to RNG. Want a new dagger? Well, you can't buy one and you won't find it on a regular monster or in a treasure chest, heck no! Better wander the same labrynths over and over again, treading back to the same designated areas where you can "ambush" the same "unsuspecting" monsters and their bizarre supply trains carrying mostly the same low level crap you don't need to nowhere in particular. Why does this make sense again?

This game's idea of "challenge" is to sometimes throw a monster 10-14 levels higher than normal into a crowd, with the same sprite as a normal mob. Forgetting to check is one of the few ways to actually die in this game that I have found. I did forget to check once. It's not that the monster quickly killed me either - it just wouldn't die and eventually it ground me out through a war of attrition from which I could not successfully flee. Challenging? No. Tedious? Yes.

I'll admit that 10 hours ain't much for a game like this. Heck, I probably spent at least 2 hours of that rolling stats in the character generator (the rolls are very stingy - prepare to roll a lot of zeros!). But in only the second dungeon, somebody thought it would be a fun mechanic to spin the party in a random direction in every intersection while simultaneously turning off your compass in intersection squares. Just... why? Why would you punish your players so? I'm just trying to fill in my map, fight monsters and get loot. Do you think I want to be stopped in my tracks multiple times and be forced to study repetitive wall textures so that I can turn myself back the way I was supposed to be going in the first place? One brilliant 4-way intersection has no distinguishing features no matter which direction you turn, so you just have to guess. Oops, wrong way! Oops wrong way! Serously. I have no patience for games that blatantly waste my time.

Yes, this game looks nice. So go look at the art somewhere, but don't waste your time or your money here. This crap might fly on a dead handheld, but not on glorious PC. There are much better games you could be playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043840291', 'num_games_owned': 602, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1500573042}
review:
This is a complex hard game in vein of early dungeon crawlers like Wizardry. This means big party of mute drones clears dungeons under your command, getting levels and gear in the process. Combat system is turn based, everybody has various abilities, it's all quite interesting.

It may feel unfair because some encounters may one shot your characters and death is not cheap in this game - revival costs money and character rests for lots of battles. There are interesting tactical puzzles here but you have to work to get there learning who to run from and who to fight. The key to power is changing classes and constructing powerful class combination. You also have to rotate your party for inevitable long revival replacement. Many of the challenges are optional or post-game so if you're hooked you have a lot of content.

The story is animesque filler. Art style can be switched between maximum anime and dark fantasy less offensive anime.

Be warned: the game only allows saving on world map. You can walk for an hour in the dungeon without an option to save, not even autosave. Very inconvenient and made me drop the game.

review: I really like the game, but it seems like there's an awful lot of guide reading, stat re-rolling and min-maxing. That, and the death system is somewhat annoying - losing just one member of the party can be a huge pain. That said... I do love this game. xD

author: {'steamid': '76561198020584337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 4615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4553, 'last_played': 1626138614}
review: I was over 70 hours in, nearly done the game, finally had my perfect team, when the "load game" option just disappeared from the main menu. I searched the forums for a solution and ended up trying to reinstall the game, after which it just immediately crashed and stuck at a white screen. The game had been crashing on me up until that point but I only ever lost 20 min or so since my last save...I tried posting in trouble shooting for help but no response after nearly a week... It's a shame because the game is pretty fun but it just crashes and breaks on you and no one seems to give a crap or want to try to help you fix it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075239964', 'num_games_owned': 246, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1120, 'last_played': 1501344467}
review:
SOSC, I have a love-hate relationship with this game honestly. It's one of the most enjoyable and well-constructed JRPG Dungeon Crawlers to come up as of late, yet is is also one of the most brutal ones. I will review only "Normal" difficulty and up, will not review "Easy". Tl;dr; A MUST-PLAY for any JRPG or Dungeon Crawler fan.

Pros:
+ Beautiful artwork.
+ Top-notch soundtrack and SFX
+ Interesting story with enough plot twists.
+ Good amount of classes, each unique on their own.
+ Game mechanics are very refined and work well.
+ Replay value is there, but only for people that want to challenge the game to its maximum.
+ Good tutorials and easy to get into.
+ In-depth character planning and building.

Cons:
+ There is a lot of grinding for gear and levels involved if you want to challenge the game at its highest difficulty.
+ A lot of planning involved in creating character builds long-term.
+ The game is hard, brutal at moments. You can fight lv 10 enemies, next fight you might be against lv 25 ones. Check before you fight. I like this, most people don't.
+ End-game and NG+ bosses are hard, like hard. Without proper builds and gear, higher difficulties will make you struggle, a lot.
+ Bonus stat roll is a horrible system. Use cheat engine to give yourself a reasonable roll if you value your sanity, or you can roll for like 30-40 minutes per character to get a +10 roll (which you need if you want to challenge NG+).

Graphics:
Game is beautiful, artwork feels very unique and J-like. The ground tiles leave something to be desired, but the characters, menus, effects and cut-scenes look amazing. 8/10.

Sound:
The sound is top-notch, character dialogues (that are voiced) feel authentic (at least with Japanese audio) and cut-scene audio feels just about right. You can choose between a lot of character sound sets for your characters. 9/10.

Gameplay:
Very in-depth character building system long-term. You can literally take hours to plan your party's classes, gear and skills. Game features a class-change system, where characters can switch from class to another, keeping skills and stats, but losing spell (for casters). Some classes serve only for their skills, some serve as a main final class. Characters can die, depending on their LP, I mean die-die, permanently, depending on their age. Critical hits kill your characters in this game, but can be prevented in certain ways. 9/10.

Story:
I won't spoil it, but the story is well-written. It gets stale at times, but has a good amount of twists that keep you guessing. Not something out of this world, but it's very unique and interesting in its own right. 8/10

Replay Ability:
8/10 for hardcore fans that want to challenge NG+ (which is, mind you, considerably harder).
3/10 for casual players that just want to experience the game.

Verdict Score: 
9/10 for J-RPG or Dungeon Crawler Fans.
6/10 for people not familiar with the JRPG genre or looking for an easy game to go through for the story.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993190168', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 6306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3243, 'last_played': 1667265339}
review:
Edit November 11, 2018: I've since played a few other Japanese dungeon crawlers (including a few Etrian Odysseys) and am very confident in recommending SoSC if they're your jam.  Game's on sale for $8 at this moment but the base price of $20 is also a decent price point IMO.  I'm at a time in my life where I don't have a lot of time to replay games but SoSC is one I frequently consider coming back to again.

July 9, 2017: If you love RPGs and JRPGs, are okay with old-school dungeon crawlers, and also fine with a game being unapolagetically hard if you don't bother to learn it's mechanics then this is a solid game that's worth the sorta-steep pricetag.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062710598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 22639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12675, 'last_played': 1639908745}
review:
best dungeon rpg ever played, 
this gem is worth every euros of its price, and then some.

the art is gorgeous, the ambiance is dark but hopefull, 
the characters are likable and your choices meaningfull.

oh yeah, i forgot to mention some negatives points : 
- the game is too easy even in normal, need an hard mode.
- new games+ are boring due to lack of difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005504491', 'num_games_owned': 440, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 4041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3096, 'last_played': 1514634709}
review: I have spent a tremendous amount of time in this game. Very fun. Be prepared to save scum alot. Hard, but not completely unforgiving. One of my favorite JRPGs recently made. I turned off the in game voice acting myself, I find the japanese voices distracting. I also changed the art style in game to 2, which is more like Fire Emblem. I also imported 16 custom made Fire Emblem images into the game which turned out awesome. I posted them all to the discussion boards for this game if anyone is interested.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136229357', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 5905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4810, 'last_played': 1627523824}
review:
Probably one of the more unique visual novels I've played in a while. You are able to create your own avatar and eventually your whole party. The gameplay is quite interesting in that you get random item drops with varying degrees of quality, so kind of like a typical dungeon crawler. Many of the maps can be done any different orders, so there is some replayability in this sense along with the item drops. One of the most interesting things though are the two different art styles they allow you to pick, which you can even change in game after you've started at virtually any time. Combat is fun and can be challenging at times if your not properly prepared with a stock of items. You don't really ever have to grind since mobs scale to your level, but with the class system that allows you to level up multile combinations it gives a lot of incentive to create strong characters. Definitly enjoyed this one and would recommend to any RPG or visual novel fan! Bought the game at full price and I believe it is well worth it.

It seems some people have experienced crashes with this game for some reason, but I did not experience any in my entire playtime under Windows 10, it should be noted though I did not install the game on the windows drive, but one of my other four.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028822780', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3381, 'last_played': 1561068349}
review:
Excellent game for those who like the single player experience of a jrpg dungeon crawler.

Focus lies on tactical decisions in battles. The story is nice and holds everything together, but is not as elaborate as those in for instance a Final Fantasy game.

You create a hero and pretty early in the game you make your party of 6 warriors, with a lot of customization. Choose among 8 classes. Multiclass to up to 5 classes at once. And all classes are useful!

Pro's:
- Long game, im at 30 hours and I expect to be half-way or a bit over
- Replay value in the decisions you make for which special powers and classes you will use.
- Expansive customization in the creation of your party. Mix and match it together the way you want!
- Difficult game! The world is status quo, and if you bring a wrong setup or are underleveled, you will die quickly.
- Grinding can be done fast with the fast battle mode, where your heroes and monsters all hit each other in rapid succession. A great way to save time!
- I love the music and art. Music is vocal and orchestrated, gives great atmosphere. Art is a mix of anime and realism in a healthy mix.

Con's:
- Items in the shop are limited. No restocking. What you use is what you lose.
- Grinding is required if you make wrong choices or lose key characters
- The difficulty can be a con if you feel you get stuck. Some boss battles are a real pain if you dont know whats coming. Fortunately, there is always the internet for some helpful hints and tips.


Overall: 9/10 for the single player jrpg dungeon crawler experience, with great music and atmosphere. Recommended for everyone who is into this game genre!

author: {'steamid': '76561198089576367', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2913, 'last_played': 1526823198}
review:
Great game...
An rpg game that forces you to play carefully because your party members can PERMANENTLY DIE.
You get to select what dungeon you want to enter then it becomes a classic 3D DOOM styled graphics dungeon crawler where you can move 1 block at a time.
The story is pretty alright, you are some special dude (or dudette) who  has woken up from a plane crash in a mysterious land, which your quest is to collect bloodstones to give to 3 factions... Or known as vessels.  apparently, giving them dem stones can change the game's story outcome soo pick wisely.

If you are having trouble with the controls, just click what you see on the screen with your mouse... this game is a port from another console probably... I dunno.

The good stuff about it:
Unique system where dying teamates can result in permanent death, too lazy to go in deph but lets just say that young party members can die a few times before perma death, while older members can die after just once.

Pretty fun grinding simulator.

Graphecs are pretty anime...

You can customise your party members to your liking, this includes stats, avatar, name, gender, race, and traits.

Cons:
You haf to w8 game hours for your fallen teamates to revive....This can be annoying to some but to be honest, it's the reason i enjoy playing this game, cuz it reminds us that DYING IS BAD.

Pro tips:  
1)Grind early on at the hide locations to arm yourselves with better gear.
2)Give your party members decent amount of vit, vit=more hp lel
3)Bring more than 1 healer with you (you are screwed if your only healer gets CC'd)
4)If the enemy looks REALLY tough, don't be stubborn and just leg it... Use your brain, not your ego.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974961727', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1488663690}
review:
Can't say I like it in short the learning curve is steep.  

A lot is dumped on you with the expectation that you can pick it up.
Graphics are very average, the battles are annoying with the number of commands you have to issue (And I loathe the final confirmation: apply, fast apply or redo). 
Also the levels of monsters you meet is very random: you can face spellcasters very early on armed with a one-cast kill spell. Yes, you get some kind of escape spell but if a group block your return to the city and you can't fight it. Well, that's just bad luck and reload your last save.
Bonus is that you can only save in the city so if you venture far off and got to quit the game, progress is not saved. While I can understand the idea, this is quite frustrating.
Add some skills such as Concentrate with a description: "Use skills which require concentrate" and good luck guessing what they do. 

From the positive comments, people seemed to enjoy it once past the beginning but I don't get the charm of the game and grinding in the very start of the labyrinth really doesn't appeal to me (and it is very slow there). I do enjoy dungeon crawl games but not that one unfortunately.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991459898', 'num_games_owned': 812, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1489096787}
review:
Really good game if you don't mind a bit of a grind. All the negative reviews seem to be because the game is crashing, it looks like most of the people who can run the game enjoy it. 

If you're the kind of person who hates slow progression or randomly getting screwed by RNG makes you super angry, you may want to avoid this game. If you have the patience to stick it out, you end up with a deep class and skill system that makes the grinding worthwhile.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993541530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6934, 'last_played': 1680404447}
review:
If you like DRPGs, SoSC is a good game to add to your list. While the translation of the story can sometimes be hit or miss, the core gameplay elements are well done and worth the play. It has a good difficulty and will get harder with multiple NG+ runs to give you a reason to keep replaying it over and over if you need to.

That being said, there is an enhanced remake that just came out for the Vita that removes some of the more trying elements of the game and adds more content; An announcement hasn't been made as to these enhancements making their way over to the PC, but we can always hope.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974905520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1488348689}
review:
Game looks beautiful, the artwork is breathtaking. The oldschool method of navigation (go forward, turn 90 degrees, go forward again) is not charming but forgivable. Unfortunately, the game crashed inevitably for me both in windowed and full screen mode. It happens at different points and without the chance to save. Therefore, I cannot give a positive review until it's stable.

Artwork: 10/10
Gameplay: 7/10
Stability: 0/10

Wait until they fix the stability issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988810433', 'num_games_owned': 1298, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1488890433}
review:
I really want to like this game. I really do, And it seems to have a promising begining. The only problem is that I can't get anyt farther then the first map, without the game crashing.  And this isn't just an isolated case either. PLenty of people are having this problem too. I dunno. If there's an update or someone finds a fix, I'd love to keep playing this game. But until then...

For the record, most of the people experiencing problems with the game constantly crashing seem to be Windows 10 users, so if you are one such person, buy at your own risk.

Edit:
I found a way to get it to run reliably. I have it installed on a drive that is not the same as my windows install (I guess for some reason that makes a difference)

The game it's self is very fun. Lots of good artwork for the characters. Definatly very grindy, with regaurds getting gear, and levels. Having characters age, and permadeath is an interesting adition that seems like it could be neat, or really annoying. I haven't really played long enough to see how much of an effect it has on things.

I guess technically I'm still in the tutorial bit of the game, but there seems to be a LOT of clutter on the headsup that I have no idea what it does. Which seems like not the greatest design choice either.  The bit that I played definatley seems to be good, but as of now, I still feel like The Etrian Odyessy Series (especially the remakes of the first 2 games, and 4) are much better examples of modern takes on FP Dungeon Crawling.

But here's the thing. I doesn't feel like that great of a port. All of the button imput prompts are "button 1" and so on, if you are using keyboard and mouse, instead of what the default keyboard buttons actually are. And then, as I mentioned above, the sheer ammount of work that I had to go through to play thte game was a little annoying too. I just feel like there could have been more work put into making this a nice stable PC game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976264359', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1488283339}
review:
For starters, the game appears to run in windowed mode as default. The game's controller method is completely broken. The mouse cursor immediately disappears, and for an unknown reason the mouse is delivering constant "move left" inputs even when not being touched. As a result the control method is unable to be manually changed. A Proprietry XBOX controller does not work at all with the program.

This title should not be for sale in its current state. I will be leaving a negative review. Steam; learn to QC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056772227', 'num_games_owned': 1074, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1203, 'last_played': 1638871009}
review:
Il titolo Ã¨ ottimo sotto gran parte delle cose che presenta.
La creazione del personaggio Ã¨ abbastanza buona e la possibilitÃ  di scegliere tra almeno quattro pagine (di cui una ventina a testa) di portait e la possilitÃ  di metterne di personalizzate tramite slot vuoti posti alla fine delle quattro pagine (utilizzando misure precise) aggiunge un tocco di personalitÃ  (e di preferenza) ancora maggiore.
Le battaglie sono composte a turni e il numero massimo di personaggi che puoi usare sono sei.
Richiede una certa strategia per sconfiggere i nemici piÃ¹ ostici ma all'inizio non si possiedono mosse/incantesimi che possano fare la differenza ed infatti il gioco richiede del farming per continuare l'avventura.
Dato che i personaggi creati sono piÃ¹ potenti (a livello di storia) non dovrai spaventarti se i nemici che incontri all'inizio sono giÃ  di livello dieci mentre tu sei ancora al primo ma rimani comunque in guardia e calcola bene chi e cosa attaccare inizialmente perchÃ¨ ti potrebbero sopraffare anche dei semplici nemici che combattevi con facilitÃ .
Se ti senti in grado di tener testa ai nemici che incontri in quel momento, hai la possibilitÃ  (prima di iniziare i turni di combattimento) di scegliere tra due metodi visivi: uno in cui vedi con calma l'andamento dei turni (dato che verranno selezionate TUTTE le azioni degli alleati che possiedi e POI inizia il turno ed infine ripetere la procedura fino a fine battaglia) e l'altro utilizza una procedura accelerata che, in pochi secondi, vengono effettuati tutti i turni in modo da farmare piÃ¹ velocemente.
Oltre al farming Ã¨ presente una feature particolare: l'imboscata.
L'imboscata Ã¨ un'azione che viene effettuata in punti precisi del dungeon (che varia in base alla zona scelta. NOTA: i dungeon non sono generati casualmente ma sono preconfigurati con alcune battaglie da affrontare forzatamente passando per certe zone. Nonostante ciÃ² ci sono comunque battaglie casuali durante l'eplorazione).
Facendo le imboscate hai la possibilita di nasconderti e attendere che un gruppo di nemici, portandosi appresso sempre uno scrigno contenente oggetti che possono variare di volta in volta, passi per quella zona e di affrontare ed eliminare tutti i nemici per prendere lo scrigno perÃ² il capo, se non viene sconfitto in fretta, potrebbe fuggire con il bottino.
Nonostante la possibilita di farmare sia come esperienza che come loot il titolo rimane comunque una sfida per chi non sa accettare la morte dei propri compagni che, in base all'etÃ , potranno avere tre, due o addirittura una sola vita che puÃ² essere recuperata facendolo dormire alla taverna ed il salvataggio Ã¨ permesso soltanto alla base.
Dopo tutto questo scrivere finisco lodando le artwork stupende che possono essere cambiate tra uno stile fantasy o dark prima di iniziare il gioco e dicendo che il titolo Ã¨ ottimo ma richiede attenzione e pazienza prima di affrontare zone e battaglie nuove.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973018655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1465843831}
review: A dungeon crawler with Wizardry-like combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041778589', 'num_games_owned': 885, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 5365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2948, 'last_played': 1495412487}
review:
Stranger of Sword city is your standard JRPG dungeon crawler(and all that implies) with several very nice quirks that makes it stand out.  Seriously though, it's a dungeon crawler. If you're looking for deep character interaction and development you shouldn't go for this one. It does have a nice world though.

1. The Game requires some thought and intelligence rather than just grinding your face against a millstone til you win.
2. Permadeath if a thing for your party, but only if you're stupid.
3. Can Create your own party and balance permadeath resistance versus power
4. The Shops don't restock their items.
5. Every class appears to be balanced so far( though not at first)
6. And auto move on the map! oh auto move how I love thee. I'd sayt his one like five times if it wasn't annoying.
7. Can grind for gear at certain "hunting" spots with a "push your luck" style of play. I hate grinding but this feels fun because you can see what type of gear(armor, sword, hat, etc) before you fight and you're garunteed to get "something" so it feeeels more like gambling than praying for a .02% loot drop.

All in all, a fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968891301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2339, 'last_played': 1485202929}
review: Very pretty.  Gameplay is exclusively grinding.  Story is forgettable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027269114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 7934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7264, 'last_played': 1558845011}
review:
A good Wizardry-like game with a great soundtrack, provided that you like synthed vocals. Recommended if you like Wizardry, Elminage, or Etrian Odyssey.

This game really nails the classic fantasy art style.

If you liked this then you may also like Laybyrinth of Refrain: Coven of Dusk. That one is developed by Nippon Ichi and has an anime art style.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127773745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 9859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1981, 'last_played': 1624249469}
review: Nice drawing!But that's it,period.As a designer myself I bought this game because Kazama Raita 's artwork.I have to say that this might be the worst RPG I've ever played in my life.I mean a good story is not all about complex like <A song of ice and fire> .A simple story can be a great one too,But the story of this game is too simple and shallow.If you could skip battles and levels just focus on the main story you would finish this game no more than 30 minutes.....Too many bad words about the scenario...Even if you are a true-love dungeon crawler, you wont enjoy this game very much due to the limited skills and strategies..However, it is  a average battle design.I would stop here.But my disappointment would last a little long..,Great art work.I mean I so wished that  I just paid for all the artworks about this game but never played it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021366827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 952, 'last_played': 1630593057}
review:
This game might become a classic, as it is a perfect example of the dungeon-crawler genre.

Yes, it is difficult.
Yes, it is punishing.
Yes, it is obscure in its mechanics and lore.

But it is good.

While this type of game is generally not well received in the west because of the aformentioned elements, it is both enjoyable and replayable.

The art style is great, as the music, and the gameply flows naturally once you get the hang of it. But it is truly a japanese dungeon-crawler, with lots and lots of farming, so if this part of the game is a problem to you, you might not want to buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086226140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 5115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5012, 'last_played': 1526363433}
review:
Be warned: This is a game of immense frustration. This is the kind of game where you can spend up to an hour trying to find a specific boss only for it to one shot kill your entire team for its first turn. There is a permanent death system that will catch up with you sooner or later and put you in a very bad position eventually. Be wary of death, you may only revive so many times before your character is gone for good. Progression demands many long hours of level grinding and equipment grinding.

Basically, this is an RPG with depth and requires immense patience, planning, and a lot of level grinding.
If you consider those positives, this game comes reccomended.

Other pros and cons include:

Pros:
Very customizable. Anyone with any knowledge of picture editing can upload custom sprites for their party members as well.
A story with good lore and characters and interesting twists.
An option in the menu to switch between two styles of art for story characters and CGs. 

Cons
Can be very cheap and frustrating in general.
Dungeons are extremely petty and mostly serve for boss hunting and level grinding.
The music is mediocre to just alright in my opinion, but can be turned off if you want to listen to something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077509684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4287, 'last_played': 1518375529}
review:
This is a great, classic turn based dungeon crawler JRPG, but it is not for those that hate repititive gameplay.


*Note/tips
-This game is not hard at all. People are just too lazy to grind and farm for better gear. I have gotten to end game with only 1 death and that is my main character (your custom character CANNOT actually die, only incapacitated for a certain amount of time).

-Learn to leave the dungeon and SAVE. If you get good gear, you should leave and SAVE. Do not risk adventuring forward only to lose all your gear or your favorite character because a boss ends up killing your party member(s).

author: {'steamid': '76561198004591477', 'num_games_owned': 978, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 7854, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7441, 'last_played': 1561551130}
review:
I had a really good time with this game, and I'd quite heartily recommend it.
If this has wet your appetite and you feel you want more, you should try Demon Gaze (same studio), or the Elminage series (competing company).

It has been a while since I played, so all the details aren't fresh in my mind, but without further ado...

[h1]What is Stranger of Sword City[/h1]
It's an unashamed old-school grid-based blobber, with many little modern conveniences.
And it's not a particularly hard one at that.

[h1]The basic gameplay loop[/h1]
You have a party of 6 people, and you run around on a variety of dungeons, fighting enemies, collecting loot and beating the snot out of bosses so you can collect McGuffins to advance the plot and get special abilities.

There are 4 ways to run into monsters.
[olist]
[*] Random encounters as you run around the level (the rate is fairly low, unless you use Force Alarm)
[*] Pre-determined spots in a map (these respawn every ingame day, and have orange (regular) or red (boss) markers on the tile)
[*] Checkpoints
[*] Ambushing
[/olist]

Ambushing is done in certain spots of each dungeon, each ambush attempt has a greator morale cost (5, 20, 35, 50, etc), and toughter enemies. You use these same morale points to invoke special abilities you unlock with the same mcGuffins.
In each ambush attempt, up to 6 groups can pass by and each that passes increases the chance that they'll get first strike by 20% - this is very dangerous so you should avoid passing on the groups early on.
Each group generally consists of a tougher mini-boss monster and some weak cannon fodder to act as meatshields for the boss. These mini-bosses escape after several turns and take the loot with them.
Ambushing is your main source of equipment and loot in general in the dungeons, and the best way to fight enemies in quick succession if you want to grind levels.

As for combat, your party of 6 is divided into a front row and a back row; the first triplet in front, the second in back.
There is a lot they don't explain about combat, eg that you can use a whistle ahead of time (it'll light up the whistle icon at the bottom) to prevent bosses from screwing up your party order once. The spell casting UI also completely sucks, I had to google how to get to my wizard's attack spells.
You issue the actions you want your party to take, and then they're "applied" either normally or fast. Several prompts show up for each action, under normal mode, you advance 1 prompt per press of a button (you can also hold it), under fast mode it'll just skip through all the prompts rapidly. After a while I found myself just quickly tapping through and relying more on sounds and the simple animations to tell me what is going on over actually reading the prompts.
However once you reach the mid game, you'll tend to just stack up +Hit and +Avoid (you can see the current values on the portraits on the top right), and pair it with Force Guard so that enemies don't dispel them to their originals levels, and there isn't much strategy left.

The one thing I don't like about combat, is just how heavily levels factor into it.
For example, if your character is level 15, and a monster attacks and it does 200 damage (just about a OHK), but you can barely hit him and do pitifully little damage. But if you level up but with no real change in equipment or stats, he now hits you for considerably less and you can do a reasonable level of damage to him.
Combat does have a fairly strategic layer to it, and you do have a lot of tools at your disposal (and you unlock more and more over time).
If you can overcome the level gap, the main game isn't hard at all.

Dungeon design leaves a bit to be desired.
I do wish they could've added a bit more in the line of puzzles, but I suppose not every game can be like Etrian Odyssey.
Every dungeon has its own unique theme and feel, and usually a unique gimmick as well.
As a few simple examples
[list]
[*] Mausoleum of Sand: features many pits you can fall through
[*] Mausoleum of Forest: Features spinners that make it hard to know where you're going
[*] Mausoleum of Fire: Has "lava" tiles that hurt you if you step on them.
[*] Mausoleum of Sea: Spells are sealed away, and there are pusher tiles to simulate currents.
[/list]

[h1]PLOT! PLOT! PLOT![/h1]
The story is fairly rudimentary and serves more as an excuse to progress from dungeon to dungeon. The characters are likeable enough and there's more than enough dialogue and exposition to allow you to get attached to the characters.
I have heard that the developer will be doing significantly more writing in future titles, I for one hope they don't because there is really nothing wrong with this level.
A lot of the dialogue is also voiced, and with Japanese voice work to boot (that's a big plus for me).

Also the translation is absolutely awful, not that I expected better from anything published by NISA, but shame on you all the same.
The best parts look and feel like a fairly literal translation taken out of google and tidied up a bit for grammar, and the worst parts are either incomprehensible or completely misleading.
The last bit plagues a great many useful items and skills!

For example, you can carry Dolls with you to save you from insta-kill attacks.
Some of them contain this in their description: Item loss rate UP.
Nearly everyone would think: "oh, I'm going to lose items if I carry this with me, oh dear!"
What that property actually means, is that there's a very good chance that the item won't break after saving you from disaster.

[h1]Character system[/h1]
The character system is fairly simple and rudimentary.
Most of the depth comes from your class selections, and then your selection of cross-class skills.
I do like how your characters' ages factors into your survivability.
I also like that your reserves slowly level up and make some money for you.

[h1]Art[/h1]
As most know, there are 2 distinct art styles available, which affects the portraits of the characters you meet, and the CG scenes you get to look at during crucial moments of the plot.
First is the Type A art style by Yoko Tsukamoto, this is a more realistic/gothic art style, and despite some of the scenes looking rushed and incomplete, it's just oozing soul, personality, and atmosphere.
Second is the Type B by En Okishiji, it's banal boring generic animu moe blob rubbish; Okishiji is clearly a talented individual, but his artwork is a terrible fit for the game, and is in general just soulless, bland, and sorely lacking in details.

There is no mincing words about how bad Type B is, using it is like watching anime with dubs; if you want to do that, all the more power to you, but I just want you to know you have absolutely awful taste.

As for how lacking in detail type B is, just go look at Rui's portraits as an easy example.
In Type A, you'll notice several very distinct and unique features, such as her eyes looking like a lizard's. This detail (that is actually very important to her character) is completely absent in the type B art.

The locations themselves aren't that great, the models are low poly and the textures are fuzzy, but do keep in mind that this game was also targeted at the Vita.
The music is also fairly decent, it's never going make it into my top 100, but it never got on my nerves while playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016432675', 'num_games_owned': 1503, 'num_reviews': 483, 'playtime_forever': 10337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10122, 'last_played': 1475857060}
review:
[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I] Masochists, or Players who follow a strict strategy guide [/i]

[b] Summary: [/b]  

Look, Dungeon crawling Japanese RPGs are meant to be difficult, they are meant to be hard, but in most cases you should be able to overcome the situation with smart play and dedication. Which is why I want to shoot Stranger of Sword City out of a cannon, burn the cannon, and then burn the ashes. When it comes to inconsistent gameplay mechanics, out of nowhere situations that screw you, and elements that just extend gameplay for no good reason, Stranger of Sword City is at the top of the list. 

Frustration is what is in store for you if you play Stranger of Sword City. Unless you follow a guide. This game is very particular about how to fight in battles, how to get equipment, etc. Anytime you go off the path (a path mind you that you don't know, and the game can mislead you on), expect to be punished with a lot of grinding to make up for it. And This is the Citizen of Grind City. You don't know grinding until you've played a dungeon crawling JRPG, but this one feels like one of the worst in terms of grinding. I mean, you can just look at the hours played on this one. And you're probably wondering â€œDragnix, why the hell did you continue to play the game if you hated it so much.â€ Well, when I receive a review copy and start it and promise a review.....to me it's a promise that I have to keep. Even if it literally kills me to do. And my god, on several occassions Stranger of Sword City had me throwing my hands up and yelling out as many swears as I could possibly think of. And more that haven't been invented. 

Look, the base concepts of the game are solid in terms of the battle system and the complex combat. There's a good game underneath the surface, one that will challenge players out there. But it's so bogged down with other elements, that you'll find yourself drowning before you can really enjoy them. Spend you time looking at other games in the genre, because Stranger of Sword City is not one I can recommend.

And oh god they are making a sequel why in gods name.

[b]Video Review: [/b]  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lYn-Zv-ua5Q

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] I do like the world that they've built here. The Strangers dynamic maeks you interested in how things will play out, and the â€œrevivalâ€ system gives good reasons on why characters need to be careful, yet implusive at the same time.
[*] At the core, there's a good battle system here that rewards strategic thinking. It can be a chess match that you have to figure out how to take down an enemy specifically, and you're always in for a fight.
[*] I like the class change system and the construction of heroes, and how you have to determine when to change a hero over to another class to make them stronger. All the skills have a use and will be needed at some point, so overlooking a class may be a mistake because they may have something you will need.
[*] Divinity system adds a bunch of strategy to gameplay. Like the morale system as a whole. 
[*] Like the fact that you HAVE to run at times. 
[*] I like the concept of the equipment gathering. Forcing you to hide out and ambush enemies to get specific pieces of equipment...ok, I dig it. 
[*] Good ensemble of music that complements the gameplay/cutscenes in question. 
[*] No performance issues of any reasonable merit. Options are reasonable. 
[/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*]  Grind City. Grind Town. Grindopolis. If you thought you've seen a game with grinding, trust me, you haven't seen it yet, until you play Stranger of Sword City. I point to the number of hours I've played. I mean, look at it. JUST LOOK AT IT.
[*]  Unnecessary lengthening of gameplay elements. Final sequence having you go through the three towers even after you beat its bosses....just why? It's not providing a challenge at that point. It's just....making me hate the game more. 
[*] The game sometimes doesn't give you the whole story. It presents options as being equal in value and that it's your choice to make, when it's clear that one option is better then the other afterward. Look, just tell me the deal so I can make the right decision. 
[*] There are boulder down the hill scenarios. Enemies doing the right actions can make a challenge that is impossible to overcome. Oh, there's 15 zombies already....what's that, you're calling another 3? Fantastic.
[*] An overreliance on the HIT and AVOID spells. Seriously, if you need any hint for this game: know that those spells are 2 of the most important in the game. Now like I said, you'll need all the spells in the end....but these two are literally the bread and butter of this game.
[*] Repetition. Repetition. Repetition. 
[*] Inconsistency. The game will change things on you without much of an after thought, even though it's established a consistent meta. Which would be fine...if it told you that the scenario had changed. Half the time, it doesn't. Hell, it can't even be consistent in its inconsistency.
[*] Sometimes you'll just have to die and find out a special element of a fight that way. Don't argue, just do it. It's easier that way. Some fights have specific strategies that don't chereograph themselves, and you'll learn by failure.
[*]  Did I mention grinding? I think I did. But let me reiterate the grinding. Because there's a lot of grinding. 
[*]  Cliff Syndrome. Basically: one mistake could mean 2-4 hours of recovery, and I'm talking down to the action kind of mistake. Bigger mistakes are punished horribly. This game is not kind to experimentation. 
[*] If you play with a controller, don't let it disconnect. You'll lose the ability to use it, as the game only seems to detect controllers upon launch.
[*]  The lack of a meaningful ending in certain scenario. It just sorta....ends.
[/list]
 
[b] If you want more reviews/information regarding games I've reviewed, visit my curator. [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861768/]Dragnix Curator [/url][/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198047669191', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 5131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5089, 'last_played': 1473289133}
review:
A number of Wizardry-alikes get made, but it's a minefield even in this well-trodden ground. Too easy, too random (aka Wizardry IV :P), too self-referential, too many random mechanics, too cheap...but the folks at Experience have proven some of the best at this old game, and SoSC is one of their best.

Stranger is on the harder, more traditional end of this company's effort; the music is epic and operatic, the monsters and the portraiture are moody oil paintings, the story is grim and mature, and the difficulty is definately nasty and intolerant of mistakes. This is a boon for those who don't usually like how the player characters of their J-DRPGs tend to be on the cute side.

The character building system is well-made, providing a great sub-classing system that is at once both full of synergy yet not absolutely mandatory. Getting all of that with so few of them is really smart. I also found the Divinities system a highlight, allowing you to go with some real decision-making reguarding how you wanna fight and build, and allowing some "tug of wars" with the bosses. The Ambush system wasn't as rough as I expected (I expected rote grinding but it was great in small bursts with that delectable DRPG risk/reward).

I did have a few problems with how automated combat works, how numbers flew up behind forward rows, and hotkeys function but these are minor quibbles.

Altogether, this is a seriously great DRPG and a good buy for anyone looking to get another one experienced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034387750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 4854, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4151, 'last_played': 1476954137}
review:
Stranger of Sword City is one of those old-school Dungeon Crawler games inspired by Wizardy and the old Might & Magic games - but it's polished and innovated on the old formula a fair bit.

It trades some of the typical 'grindiness' inherent in the genre with fast paced (though still turn-based) combat and an addictive class-building system where you get to multiclass and transfer select abilities from one class to the other.

This leads to pretty amazing combinations. Picture the Samurai's ability to keep attacking until he gets hit by a counter-attack combined with a ninja's evasion - or a ranger's infinite concentration length with a warrior's 7-hits while in concentration genocide.

SoSC also isn't afraid to give you a decent bit of counters against the RNG that is king in so many dungeon crawler games. Many games in this genre rely on enemies abilities to debilitate or even insta-kill your characters... these are all present in SoSC, but there's counters available if you've played and built your characters cleverly against every single one of these - and while there's stilla decent amuont of grindy 'trash' encounters, most combats actually require a decent bit of thinking before you press the 'commit turn' button.

Your main way to improve your characters, asides from leveling up, is of course gear progression - and here also, SoSC innovates with the 'ambush' system, where - provided you can find the ambush spots in dungeons, you get to pick a fight seeing the reward type and the enemy you'd have to fight for it. 
'Hrm, lvl 20 demon for a rare katana, or a lvl 5 bunny for a few common helmets?" type of deal.

Oh, and fairly rare in this type of game, there's 3 seperate ending paths that diverge quite a bit in your final resolution.

That said, SoSC still relies quite heavily on grinding it's content to keep your characters of a sufficient level, which I had little patience for (and thus evaded by checking 'recomended levels' on the wiki, and cheating my characters up a level or two per dungeon, rather than grind through the trash for extra hours for the same effect).
That didn't stop this brutal game from murdering me a whole bunch of times, but I still greatly enjoyed the journey.

If you like old school dungeon crawler type gameplay, I'd say Stranger of Sword City feels instantly familiar, while still being innovative and very much 'it's own game'. Highly recommended.

If you *don't* care much for dungeon crawler style games though - give it a miss. Nothing here takes it far enough outside of the scope of it's genre to appeal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018948430', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 92, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1565852195}
review: It's okay if you like punishingly difficult Wizardry-Likes.  The art direction is nice, but the quality seems inconsistent at times.  If you like Etrian Odyssey, but thought that it was too easy, the grind too short, and full of too many quality-of-life improvements, then this is the game for you.  For anyone else, this is going to seem like an unfun slog.

review:
Stranger of Sword City es un Dungeon Crawler, es decir, un juego de exploraciÃ³n de mazmorras en primera persona inspirado en los juegos de rol clÃ¡sicos, pero con una estÃ©tica muy japonesa. El juego hereda la jugabilidad y mecÃ¡nicas de los RPGs de antaÃ±o, y eso incluye la dificultad de guardar la partida solo en determinados lugares. Por lo tanto, tenÃ©is que tener en cuenta que mÃ¡s allÃ¡ del bonito arte estamos ante un juego de mazmorra pura y dura y puede que no sea para todo el mundo.

El sistema de combate es por turnos y podremos llevar un mÃ¡ximo de 6 personajes que crearemos a nuestro gusto.  En batalla se nos muestran las acciones bÃ¡sicas de ataque, defensa, magia, objeto y habilidades especiales, pero tambiÃ©n opciones relacionadas con la "divinidad", un poder que otorga al elegido habilidades Ãºnicas que gastarÃ¡n puntos de moral, estos puntos se recargan automÃ¡ticamente al vencer combates. 

Es un juego muy entrentenido para amantes del gÃ©nero y para aquellos que disfrutaron de los old school.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044087373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 681, 'last_played': 1469196754}
review:
I wanted to like this game. It has so much going for it. The art is fantastic, the atmosphere is compelling, and the characters are (mostly) pretty interesting. But after playing through the first few dungeons, I just couldn't ignore some of the more annoying flaws with the game. Worst of all was how character deaths are handled. 

When you create each character, you decide how old they are. This determines how many lives they have (how many times they can die in combat before being gone forever), and how big of a stat bonus they get at creation. Older characters will have significantly higher stats but will only be able to die once before you lose that character entirely along with any equipment they had. So in order to have a character that can actually survive playing the game (because unless you want to grind out levels until you're certain nobody in your party can die to a certain boss, most of your characters will eventually die at least once), you have to sacrifice 5-7 levels worth of stat bonuses. That's the stat difference between a character with one life as opposed to one with two. The good part is that you can recover those lives if you choose to create a character with at least two maximum lives. This sounds great at first, but then you find out that it takes a VERY long time to first revive a fallen party member, and then it takes even longer to recover lost lives. The solution: have backup party members so you can switch them out with fallen ones to keep going through dungeons. This means that you have to do twice as much work maintaining backup members that do not gain experience unless they are in your party. All in all, there's just WAY too much inevitable grind in this game, and any minor character death feels like a game over.

The game was fun for a while, but instead of progressing into being more challenging and rewarding, it just progressed into being more punishing and frustrating because of the amount of work it takes to catch back up after a character death.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054841422', 'num_games_owned': 2274, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 5719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4241, 'last_played': 1695187348}
review:
Ok here it is...this game is very awesome _IF_ you're interested in playing an old school console dungeon crawler ala Shining in the Darknes (Genesis) or Arcana (SNES).  It's _NOT_ a modern PC dungeon crawler by any stretch...BUT if you are itching for that old school grindy goodness, this title won't disappoint. 

Graphics 8
Music/Sound 9
Control 6
Overall 8.5

+++++++++++++++++++++UPDATE+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

After spending 60+ hours on SOSC my review still stands with a caveat: this game is REALLY stacked against you. When other reviews say some pre-planning is involved...plan to restart this game a few times before you grasp what will work best for you.  Slogging around with your original party can be both fun and frustrating...
